(b)  If the commission determines an existing town contract or other agreement to be ethically improper, the commission may request referral of the matter to the town attorney for review. The town attorney's office shall report its findings to the commission. 
(Ord. of 1-16-2008, § 1-23) 
Sec. 2-33.24. - Confidentiality. 
(a)  No member of the commission nor any town representative who has access to any confidential information related to the functions or activities of the commission shall divulge that information to any person who is not authorized to have it. 
(b)  After a complaint has been filed and until such time as the commission may find probable cause, no member of the commission may communicate directly or indirectly with any party or other person about any issue of fact or law regarding the complaint, except that: 
(1)  The members of the commission may obtain legal advice from the town attorney and may discuss the complaint with their staff; and 
(2)  The members of the commission may discuss the complaint with the complainant, respondent, witnesses and others in the context of the confidential commission proceedings. 
(Ord. of 1-16-2008, § 1-24) 
Sec. 2-33.25. - Statute of limitations. 
    No action may be taken on any complaint which is filed later than two years after a violation of this division is alleged to have occurred, providing that a complaint alleging the violation is filed within six months from the date the complainant knew or should have known of the action alleged to be a violation. 
(Ord. of 1-16-2008, § 1-25) 
Subdivision VIII. - Interpretation 

Sec. 2-33.26. - Construction. 
    The provisions of this division are to be construed to the end that the public interest is fully protected, and shall be construed in a manner consistent with all applicable federal and state laws and applicable provisions of the Charter. In the event of a conflict between any provision of this division and any applicable federal, state or town Charter provision, the federal, state or town Charter provision shall control. To the extent permitted by law, all ordinances, resolutions or rules, and parts of ordinances, resolutions or rules inconsistent with this division are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. of 1-16-2008, § 1-26) 
Sec. 2-33.27. - Severability. 
    If any provision of this division is held by any court or by any federal or state agency of competent jurisdiction to be invalid as conflicting with any federal, state or town Charter provision now or hereafter in effect, or is held by any such court or agency to be modified in any way to conform to the requirement of any such provision, the conflicting provision of this division shall be considered a separate, distinct and independent part of this division, and such holding shall not affect the validity and enforceability of the division as a whole, or any part other than the part declared to be invalid. 
(Ord. of 1-16-2008, § 1-27) 
Secs. 2-34-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RETIREMENT SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Retirement of municipal employees, G.S. § 7-425 et seq. 

Sec. 2-51. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a retirement system for employees of the town, commencing in and for the fiscal year of July 1, 1967, to June 30, 1968, and continuing thereafter. 
(Ord. of 8-1-1967, § 1) 
Sec. 2-52. - Administration generally. 
    The board of finance and the board of selectmen, or any successor or successors to their powers, are hereby authorized to establish, administer and maintain a retirement system for the employees of the town; and to make provision, by regulations, appointment of boards, committees, agencies or commissions, for the establishment, administration and maintenance of said retirement system. 
(Ord. of 8-1-1967, § 2) 
Sec. 2-53. - Appropriations. 
    The retirement system established by this division may be financed by appropriation of town funds, contributions by employees, an insurance policy or policies, trust funds, general contributions or bequests, or any other legal, actuarily and fiscally sound means. 
(Ord. of 8-1-1967, § 3) 
Sec. 2-54. - Other benefits. 
    The retirement system established in this division may be administered in conjunction with or in the light of other retirement or pension benefits presently or in the future equitably available to the beneficiaries thereof. 
(Ord. of 8-1-1967, § 4) 
Sec. 2-55. - Benefits for dependents, survivors. 
    The retirement system established by this division may provide benefits for dependents and/or survivors of the town employees and may be administered jointly or in conjunction with any other benefits or plan of benefits presently or in the future equitably available to town employees, their dependents and/or survivors. 
(Ord. of 8-1-1967, § 5) 
Sec. 2-56. - Volunteer members of the town fire department. 
    Effective on and after July 1, 1998, volunteer members of the town fire department shall be eligible to participate in such retirement plan as shall be established or amended, from time to time, by the board of selectmen, or any successor or successors to its powers. The board of selectmen, or any successor or successors to its powers, is hereby authorized to establish, administer and maintain a retirement system for the volunteer members of the town volunteer fire department and to make provision, by regulations, for the establishment, administration and maintenance of said retirement system. Said retirement system shall be financed and administered in such manner as the board of selectmen may prescribe. 
(Ord. of 5-24-1999) 
Secs. 2-57-2-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Appointed boards and commissions, ch. VIII. 
Cross reference- Emergency preparedness advisory council, § 7-22; economic development commission, § 14-21 et seq.; planning and zoning commission, § 14-41 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-91. - Nonrestrictive voting at elections for members of the board of education. 
    The town hereby adopts the provisions of G.S. § 9-20b in order to implement nonrestrictive voting at elections for members of the board of education. Accordingly, each political party shall have the right to nominate as many persons as there are vacancies on the board of education and those names shall be placed upon the ballot. Whether the number of members to be elected is odd or even, any elector may vote for all of that number and the persons receiving the greatest number of votes shall be elected, except that when the number of members of any one political party who would be elected without regard to G.S. § 9-167a exceeds the maximum number as determined by that section, then only the candidates of such political party with the highest number of votes up to the limit of such maximum, shall be elected. The next highest ranking candidates, not from such political party shall be elected, up to the number of places to be filled in such election. 
(Ord. of 3-4-2009) 
Secs. 2-92-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF FINANCE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Town board of finance, G.S. § 7-340 et seq. 

Sec. 2-111. - Alternate members of board of finance. 
    Pursuant to G.S. § 7-340, and subject to the provisions of G.S. § 9-167a concerning minority representation of political parties, there shall be elected on the first Tuesday of November, 1979, three alternate members of the board of finance to serve electors and taxpayers of the town. If a regular member of such board is absent or is disqualified, such absent or disqualified member shall designate an alternate to so act. In the event that an absent or disqualified regular member shall fail or refuse to designate an alternate to so act, the majority of the regular members of the board of finance not absent and not disqualified may designate an alternate subject to the provisions of G.S. § 9-167a, to so act for such absent or disqualified member. 
(Ord. of 7-10-1979) 
Secs. 2-112-2-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONSERVATION COMMISSION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- At the discretion of the editor, provisions enacted by an ordinance adopted Dec. 10, 1993, have been included herein as div. 3, §§ 2-121, 2-122. 

Sec. 2-121. - Establishment; membership; appointment; terms of office; chairperson. 
    Pursuant to section 804 of the Charter of the town, there is established a commission known as the conservation commission. Pursuant to section 804(3) of the Charter of the town, said commission shall consist of five members serving four-year overlapping terms. The five members shall be appointed and serve as follows: no later than the December 31, 1993, the board of selectmen shall appoint five commissioners, two of whom shall be designated to serve for one year, one of whom shall be designated to serve for two years, one of whom shall be designated to serve for three years and one of whom shall be designated to serve for four years. Annually thereafter as initial terms expire, all commissioners shall be appointed to serve for four years, pursuant to sections 407 and 802 of the Charter. The commission shall elect a chairperson at the first meeting of the new commission in 1994 and, thereafter, at its first meeting in each subsequent year. 
(Ord. of 12-10-1993) 
Sec. 2-122. - Powers and duties. 
    The commission shall have all the powers and shall perform such duties not inconsistent with the Charter of the town as are now or may hereafter be conferred or imposed on a municipal conservation commission by section 7-131a of the state general statutes, as amended. 
(Ord. of 12-10-1993) 
DIVISION 4. - PARTICIPATION IN THE CONNECTICUT RIVER VALLEY COUNCIL OF ELECTED OFFICIALS 

Sec. 2-123. - Authorization to form and join the Connecticut River Valley Council of Elected Officials. 
    To authorize the board of selectmen pursuant to G.S. § 4-124c, to form and join a regional organization, known as the Connecticut River Valley Council of Elected Officials, with those powers and for those purposes set forth in G.S. § 4-124c through 4-124h, as the same may, from time to time, be amended. 
(Ord. of 1-26-2000) 
Sec. 2-124. - Representation. 
    The representation to the Connecticut River Valley Council of Elected Officials shall be the chief elected official of the town. 
(Ord. of 1-26-2000) 
Secs. 2-125-2-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CITATION HEARING PROCEDURE 

Sec. 2-141. - Appointment of hearing officer. 
    Immediately upon adoption of thE ordinance from which this article derives, the first selectman shall appoint one or more hearing officers to conduct hearings authorized by this article. Said hearing officer(s) shall not be a police officer, enforcement official as hereafter defined, or employee of the Town of Portland. Said hearing officers shall serve until such time as his or her replacement is designated by the first selectman. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2012, § 1) 
Sec. 2-142. - Advisory notice to cited individual. 
    Within the period set forth below, the official who issued the citation for violation of any town ordinance (hereafter referred to as "enforcement official") may send an advisory notice to the cited individual. Such advisory notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, and by first class mail, postage prepaid. The period within which said advisory notice may be provided is the 12-month period following expiration of the final period for the payment of all fines, penalties, fees and/or costs imposed by the citation. Said advisory notice shall be directed to the last known address of the Cited Individual. 
    Such advisory notice shall contain the following information: 
(a)  A list of the allegations against the Cited Individual and the amount of fines, penalties, fees and/or costs due; 
(b)  A statement that the cited individual may contest his liability before a citation hearing officer by delivering in person or by mail written notice to the enforcement official who issued the citation within ten days of the date of the advisory notice; and 
(c)  A statement that if the cited individual does not demand such a hearing, an assessment and judgment shall be entered against him; and 
(d)  That said judgment shall issue without further notice. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2012, § 2) 
Sec. 2-143. - Admission of liability; request for hearing; hearing notice. 
    If the cited individual who has been sent an advisory notice wishes to admit liability for any alleged violation, he may, without requesting a hearing, pay the full amount of the fines, penalties, fees and/or costs to the finance director of the Town of Portland. Such payment shall be inadmissible in any civil or criminal proceeding to establish the conduct of the cited individual. 
    Any cited individual who fails to deliver or mail written demand for a hearing within ten days of the date of the advisory notice shall be deemed to have admitted liability, and the enforcement official shall so certify to the hearing officer. The hearing officer shall immediately thereafter enter and assess the fines, penalties, fees and/or costs provided for by the applicable ordinances and shall follow the procedure set forth in section 2-146 below. 
    Any cited individual who requests a hearing shall be given a written hearing notice of the date, time and place for such hearing. Said hearing notice shall be provided by the hearing officer, who shall provide a copy of same to the enforcement official. The hearing shall be held not less than 15 days nor more than 30 days from the date of mailing of the hearing notice, provided the hearing officer shall grant upon good cause shown any reasonable request by any interested party for postponement or continuance. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2012, § 3) 
Sec. 2-144. - Hearing. 
    An original or certified copy of the original citation shall be retained by the enforcement official and shall be deemed to be a business record as provided by the Connecticut General Statutes and shall be evidence of the facts contained therein. The enforcement official must attend the hearing if the cited individual so requests. The enforcement official or other town official may present evidence on behalf of the town before the hearing officer. 
    Unless excused by the hearing officer, the cited individual must attend the hearing and may present evidence in his behalf. The hearing officer may excuse the cited individual from attending the hearing only where he has previously received from the cited individual, by mail, copies of police reports or other investigatory reports which he believes renders unnecessary the appearance of the cited individual. 
    If the cited individual fails to appear, the hearing officer may enter an assessment by default against him upon a finding of proper hearing notice and liability under the applicable ordinance(s). 
    The hearing officer shall conduct the hearing in the order and form and with such methods of proof as he deems fair and appropriate. All testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation, but the rules of evidence shall not be strictly applied. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2012, § 4) 
Sec. 2-145. - Decision. 
    The hearing officer shall announce his decision at the end of the hearing. If he determines that the cited individual is not liable, he shall dismiss the matter and enter his determination in writing accordingly. If he determines that the cited individual is liable for the violation, he shall forthwith enter and assess the fines, penalties, fees and/or costs against the cited individual as provided by the applicable town ordinance(s). 
(Ord. of 6-6-2012, § 5) 
Sec. 2-146. - Payment of assessment; assessment notice. 
    If such assessment is not paid on the date of its entry, the hearing officer shall send by first class mail an assessment notice to the cited individual who has been found liable and shall file, not less than 30 days nor more than 12 months after such mailing, a certify certified copy of the assessment notice with the clerk of superior court for Middlesex County, together with an entry fee as prescribed by G.S. § 7-152c(f), to be paid by the Town of Portland. The certified copy of said assessment notice shall constitute a record of assessment. Within such 12-month period, assessments against the same individual may be accrued and filed as one record of assessment. 
    Upon entry of judgment by the court clerk, the hearing officer's assessment shall have the effect of a civil money judgment and a levy of execution of such judgment may issue without further notice to such individual. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2012, § 6) 
Sec. 2-147. - Appeal rights. 
    Pursuant to G.S. § 7-152c(g), as amended, the individual against whom an assessment is entered is entitled to judicial review by way of appeal. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2012, § 7) 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

Sec. 3-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted May 16, 2012, repealed § 3-1, which pertained to Sunday sale of liquor and derived from an ordinance adopted Dec. 18, 1980. 
Chapter 4 - AMUSEMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 13. 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for amusements, G.S. § 7-148(c)(4)(C); authority to regulate and license amusement parks and arcades, G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(H)(vi); authority to prohibit, restrain, license and regulate sports, exhibitions, public amusements and performances and all places where games may be played, G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(H)(vii); amusements, in general, G.S. §§ 29-129-29-143a. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Entertainments, concerts, celebrations. 
    The town, through its board of selectmen and board of finance, is hereafter empowered to provide for entertainments, concerts and celebrations. 
(Ord. of 5-26-1938) 
Sec. 4-2. - Adoption of bazaar and raffle law. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of G.S. § 7-171 there are hereby adopted the bazaar and raffle law provisions as set forth in G.S. §§ 7-170 to 7-186, inclusive. 
(Ord. of 7-14-1988) 
Secs. 4-3-4-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT MACHINES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coin-operated amusement machine means any machine which upon the insertion of a coin, slug, or token, or upon payment of a charge, registers score by striking pins, levers, or bumpers or by falling into holes or slots, or which upon insertion of a coin, slug, or token or upon payment of a charge is operated electronically to register a score or tally of any kind. It shall include such devices as pinball or pin-game machines, computer games, television games, and coin operated table games (e.g., pool, bumper pool, hockey, soccer, bowling, football). 
    Distributor means any person who owns or distributes any such machine as part of its bona fide business. 
    Operator means any person who provides any such machine for use by the public as part of its bona fide business. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 2) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-22. - Gambling devices not permitted. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall in any way be construed to authorize or permit any gambling device whatsoever or any mechanism that has been judicially determined to be a gambling device or in any way contrary to law, or that may be contrary to any future laws of the state. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 3) 
Sec. 4-23. - Prohibitions and restrictions. 
(a)  Each operator, and each servant, agent and employee of each operator, shall maintain good order in his place of business and not permit any coin-operated amusement machine to be used for gambling. 
(b)  No person shall be permitted to play any coin-operated amusement machine or be allowed to congregate in such place of business if he is under 18 years of age, unless accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(c)  Any place of business containing three or more coin-operated amusement machines shall not operate such machines between 11:00 p.m. and 11:00 a.m. The provision of this section regarding hours of operation shall be inapplicable to any premises under the jurisdiction of the state division of liquor control, provided permission for such devices has been obtained from such authority. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 9) 
Sec. 4-24. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined in accordance with section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 11) 
Secs. 4-25-4-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, ch. 11. 

Sec. 4-41. - Required. 
(a)  Every distributor shall obtain a license from the first selectman for each coin-operated amusement machine owned or distributed by him. 
(b)  Every operator shall obtain a license from the first selectman for each coin-operated amusement machine in operation at his place of business. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 4) 
Sec. 4-42. - Application. 
    The application for a license under the provisions of this division shall be made to the first selectman upon forms supplied by him for that purpose and shall contain the following information under oath: 
(1)  Name of applicants; if a partnership, names of all partners; if a corporation, club, or association, names of officers. 
(2)  Residence of applicants. 
(3)  Age of applicants; if a corporation, club or association, date organized, and under laws of what state. 
(4)  Type of business or activity. 
(5)  Whether applicants, or if a corporation, club or association, officers, have ever been convicted of a crime. 
(6)  Place where machine or device is to be displayed or operated and the business or activity conducted at that place. This shall apply only to the operator. 
(7)  Description or type of machine to be covered by the license. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 5) 
Sec. 4-43. - Investigation of applicants. 
    The first selectman shall investigate the character and record of the applicants for a license under the provisions of this division and the location wherein it is proposed to operate the machine or machines described in the application and shall not approve such application or issue a license unless it finds that the applicants are over 18 years of age and that the business or activity in such a location is a lawful one. In any case of the denial or refusal to grant or renew a license, the first selectman shall notify the applicant of his proposed action and set a day and place for a hearing thereon, giving the applicant reasonable notice in advance thereof and an opportunity to be represented by counsel at such hearing. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 6) 
Sec. 4-44. - Fees. 
(a)  A license required by the provisions of this division shall be issued by the first selectman in the name of each applicant. An annual license fee, or fraction thereof, shall be paid for each machine licensed under this division as follows: 
(1)  Distributor. Coin-operated amusement machines, $50.00 per machine. 
(2)  Operator. Coin-operated amusement machines, $50.00 per machine. 
(3)  Pool tables. In accordance with G.S. § 53-280. 
(b)  The license fees imposed by this section shall become due and payable on January 1 of each year, or on the date on which each machine is first placed in operation. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 7) 
Sec. 4-45. - Display. 
    The license required by this division shall be posted permanently and conspicuously at the location of the machine or device in the premises wherein the machine or device is to be operated or maintained. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 8(a)) 
Sec. 4-46. - Exclusive to individual machine. 
    Any license issued under this division may be transferred from one machine to another similar machine or device without the necessity of making an application therefor. Not more than one machine or device shall be distributed, displayed or operated under one license and a separate license shall be required for each and every machine or device so displayed, distributed or operated. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 8(b)) 
Sec. 4-47. - Change of location; transfer of business. 
    Each applicant for a license under the provisions of this division shall notify the first selectman promptly of any change in the ownership of his place of business or any other change in the information set forth in the original application. In the event of a sale or transfer of the business of the operator a new license must be obtained. Any distributor may be permitted, at the discretion of the first selectman to file with him the information required under section 4-42 and may thereafter not be required to furnish such information upon the signing of each separate application, but such distributor shall notify the first selectman promptly of any change in such information. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 8) 
Sec. 4-48. - Revocation. 
    The first selectman shall have the power to revoke any license issued under the provisions of this division for cause, after due notice in writing to the licensee and a hearing to be held not less than ten days after the date of such notice. Cause shall be deemed to include, but shall not be limited to, conviction of a crime involving moral turpitude subsequent to the issuance of the license, false information in the application for a license knowingly given, or any violation of this article. 
(Ord. of 10-29-1981, § 10) 
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate animals, G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(D). 

Sec. 5-1. - Feeding of raccoons and other wild animals prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall feed, harbor or shelter raccoons, feral cats, foxes, coyotes, woodchucks or skunks within the town. 
(b)  No person or business entity shall leave waste food products, and containers, garbage or other similar refuse attractive to such animals outside of an enclosed structure unless the same are contained within appropriate trash or refuse receptacles so maintained as to minimize access by such animals. 
(c)  The director of health for the town is hereby authorized to add additional species to this prohibition from time to time as such director deems necessary, and upon review and approval of the board of selectmen. 
(d)  Any person who violates any provision of this section will be issued a warning for the first violation. Any person who violates any provision of this section after receiving the first violation warning shall be subject to a fine of $50.00 for each violation, and each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. of 8-12-1992, §§ 1-4) 
Editor's note- Provisions enacted by §§ 1-4 of an ordinance adopted Aug. 12, 1992, have been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as § 5-1. 
Sec. 5-2. - Removal of dog litter. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, keeping, walking or in control of any dog to allow or permit such animal to defecate upon any sidewalk or any other public or private property maintained for human use, other than property of the owner or his agent, unless such person shall remove all feces so deposited by such animal before leaving the immediate premises. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to a guide dog accompanying any blind person. 
(c)  Anyone in violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00. 
(Ord. of 5-3-1995) 
Cross reference- Litter on highways, § 9-1. 
Editor's note- At the discretion of the editor, provisions enacted by an ordinance adopted May 3, 1995, have been included herein as § 5-2. 
Sec. 5-3. - Roaming and nuisance animals. 
(a)  No owner of any animal shall allow such animal to create a nuisance or roam at large within the town while it is not in control, by means of a leash not to exceed eight feet in length held continuously in the hands of a responsible person capable of controlling it, provided that nothing in this section shall be construed to limit or prohibit the use of hunting dogs during the open hunting or training season or any animal while performing or being exhibited in a bench show or exhibition. This does not apply to lawfully owned farm animals. 
    It shall be unlawful and an infraction of this chapter for any person within the town to allow any animal to roam uninvited on private property owned by someone other than the owner of the animal. 
(b)  If an animal is found at large in violation of this section, it shall be impounded by the animal control officer. 
(c)  Violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $100.00. 
(Ord. of 10-8-1997; Ord. of 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 5-4. - Regulation of vicious dogs. 
(a)  Purpose. It is hereby declared that vicious dogs have become a serious threat to the safety and welfare of the citizens of our community. Unprovoked attacks by vicious dogs upon persons and animals throughout the country have occurred at an increasing rate and the existing laws are inadequate to deal with the threat to the public. The owning, keeping or harboring of vicious dogs is a nuisance and many of the attacks have been attributed to the failure of owners to register, confine and properly control their vicious dogs. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following words and terms shall have the following meanings unless the context shall indicate another or different meaning or intent: 
    Domestic animals: Includes, but is not limited to, all forms of livestock. 
    Enclosure: A fence or structure not more than six feet in height and at least five by ten feet, forming or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and suitable to confine a vicious dog in conjunction with other measures which may be taken by the owner or keeper, such as tethering of the vicious dog. Such "enclosure" shall be securely enclosed, locked, designed with secure sides, top and bottom, designed to prevent the dog from escaping the enclosure and also provide the dog protection from the elements. 
    Impounded: Taken into custody of the municipal dog pound. 
    Owner: Any natural person or legal entity including, but not limited to, a firm, corporation, organization, partnership or trust, possessing, harboring, having, keeping an interest in or having control or custody of the dog. 
    Panel: A panel of three individuals, which shall include the first selectman, one veterinarian licensed in the state and the health officer. 
    Vicious dog: A dog is not "vicious" by virtue of any past behavior or propensity until the panel makes the determination based upon evidence presented to it that a dog: 
(1)  Which bites, inflicts injury, assaults or otherwise attacks a human being or domestic animal without provocation on public or private property; is owned or harbored primarily, or in part, for the purpose of dog fighting or any dog trained for dog fighting; 
(2)  Notwithstanding the definition of a "vicious dog" above, no dog may be declared vicious if an injury or damage is sustained by a person who, at the time such injury or damage was sustained, was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon premises occupied by the owner of the dog or was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(3)  No dog may be declared vicious if an injury or damage was sustained by a domestic animal, which at the time that such injury or damage was sustained, was teasing, tormenting or assaulting the dog. No dog may be declared vicious if the dog was protecting or defending a human being within the immediate vicinity of the dog from an unjustified attack or assault. 
(c)  Control of vicious dogs. All vicious dogs shall be confined in an enclosure. It shall be unlawful for any owner to maintain a vicious dog upon any premises which does not have a locked enclosure. It shall be unlawful for an owner of a vicious dog to permit the dog to be outside the enclosure unless the dog is securely muzzled and restrained with a chain type leash and under the direct control and supervision of the said owner. The chain shall have a minimum tensile strength of 300 pounds and not exceed three feet in length. The muzzle shall be made in such a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration but shall prevent it from biting any person or animal. The owner shall display a sign on the premises warning others of a vicious dog on the premises. Said sign shall be visible and capable of being read from the street, road or highway, whether public or private, which abuts said premises. 
(d)  Prohibited activities. No person shall own or harbor any dog for the purpose of dog fighting or train, torment, badger, bait or use any dog for the purpose of causing or encouraging said dog to unprovoked attacks upon human beings or domestic animals. 
(e)  Impoundment; issuance of citations; hearing procedures; appeals. 
(1)  In the event the animal control officer has probable cause to believe that a dog is vicious, upon notification the first selectman, or his designee, shall be empowered to convene a hearing for the purpose of determining whether or not the dog in question should be declared vicious. The first selectman, or his designee, shall notify the owner of the dog that a hearing will be held, at which time such owner shall have the opportunity to present evidence why the dog should not be declared vicious. The hearing shall be conducted by the panel. Said hearing shall be held promptly within no less than five days but no more than ten days after service of notice upon the owner of the dog. The hearing shall be open to the public. 
(2)  After the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be notified in writing of the decision. If a decision is made that the dog is vicious, the owner shall comply with the provisions of this section in accordance with a time schedule established by the animal control officer or his designee, but in no case more than 30 days subsequent to the date of the determination. If the owner of the dog contests the determination, he may request a hearing before the state commission of agriculture when such is provided by G.S. § 22-358. 
(3)  In the event the animal control officer has probable cause to believe the dog in question is vicious and may pose a threat of serious harm to human beings or domestic animals, the animal control officer shall seize and impound the dog pending the hearing. The owner of the dog shall be liable to the town for the costs and expenses, including shelter, food and veterinary expenses, necessitated by the seizure of such dog. 
(f)  Violations and penalties. 
(1)  Any vicious dog which is not maintained within an enclosure on the premises or outside of the dwelling of the owner or outside of an enclosure and unmuzzled and/or unchained, as provided herein, shall be confiscated by the animal control officer and impounded for a period of 14 days. Following the second impoundment under this section, the dog may be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner, but only after written notice to the owner of a hearing and order of the animal control officer. The owner may request a hearing before the state commission of agriculture, when such is provided for by G.S. § 22-358, or when not so provided, then by the panel within 14 days of said order. In the event that the owner requests said hearing, the destruction of the dog shall be stayed until such time as the commissioner of agriculture affirms the order of the animal control officer. In addition, the owner shall pay a fine of $99.00 and such costs and expenses necessitated by each seizure of the dog, including such expenses as may be required for the destruction of such dog. 
(2)  If any vicious dog should attack, assault, wound, bite or otherwise injure or kill a human being or domestic animal, when unprovoked, the owner of said dog shall pay a fine of $99.00 and the animal control officer is empowered to confiscate and impound said dog for a period of 14 days. Following impoundment under this section, the dog may be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner but only after the owner has been advised by written notice of a hearing and order of the animal control officer. The owner may request a hearing before the commissioner of agriculture, when such is provided for by G.S. § 22-358, or when not so provided, then by the panel within 14 days of the issuance of said order. In the event the owner requests said hearing, the destruction of the dog shall be stayed until such time as the commissioner affirms the order of the animal control officer. In addition, the owner shall pay such costs and expenses necessitated by the seizure of the dog, including such expenses as may be required for the destruction of such dog. The penalties set forth herein shall not limit the right of any victim to bring a civil action against the owner or keeper of a vicious dog, as provided for by state law. 
(g)  Responsibility of parents for ensuring compliance. In the event the owner of the vicious dog is a minor, the parent or guardian shall be responsible for ensuring compliance with this section. 
(h)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Kennels licensed in accordance with G.S. title 22, ch. 435. 
(2)  K-9 or other dogs owned by the police department or any law enforcement officer, which are used in the performance of police work. 
(Ord. of 9-27-2000) 
Chapter 6 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 8; housing, ch. 10; planning, ch. 14; streets and sidewalks, ch. 17; utilities, ch. 20; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- State building code applicable to all municipalities, G.S. § 29-253. 

Sec. 6-1. - Building permit fees. 
    The schedule of building permit fees shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such fees is on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Ord. of 5-4-1964; Ord. of 5-25-1978; Ord. of 1-1-1987) 
Sec. 6-2. - Demolition of buildings and structures. 
(a)  No person shall demolish any building, structure, or part thereof, without first obtaining a permit from the town. No permit shall be issued until the applicant: 
(1)  Files an application for demolition permit with the town under a form provided by the town which shall contain, in addition to other such information which may be required, the name and address of the owner of the building or structure to be demolished and the address of the building/structure to be demolished; and 
(2)  Certificates to the town that the premises to be demolished are free from rodent infestation; and 
(3)  Submits to the town information certifying the age of the structure proposed for demolition. 
(b)  No person shall be issued a demolition permit unless the provisions of all state statutes and all town ordinances pertaining to the issue of such permits are fully complied with. 
(c)  In addition, for any application to demolish a building, structure or part thereof, which is 75 years old (or older), the town shall: 
(1)  Within five working days following the filing of the demolition permit application, provide, by first class mail, a copy of the application to any individual, firm, corporation, organization or other entity concerned with historic preservation who is registered with the town requesting such notification. 
(2)  Establish a notification register. To be entitled to notification under this provision, any person shall register with the town and indicate a desire to be notified of demolition permit applications. Such registration must be renewed annually each January 1. The annual registration fee shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such fee is on file in the town clerk's office. 
(d)  If a written objection to the issuance of the demolition permit for a 75-year-old (or older) building, structure or part thereof is filed with the town and a copy of the objection is mailed, by first class mail, to the applicant within 30 days following the application, the town shall delay issuance of the permit for a period of 90 days from the date of application; provided, however, that the objecting person is attempting to present some reasonable alternative to demolition. 
(e)  If no objection to the demolition of the subject building, structure or part thereof is filed within 30 days after application, the town may issue the permit, forthwith or, if the application for demolition is not withdrawn by the end of the 90-day period, the demolition permit shall be issued. 
(f)  Demolition permits issued under this section shall be valid for a period of not more than one year following the issuance of the permit by the town. If the demolition approved under the permit is not completed within the one-year time period, a new permit application and permit approval will be required prior to the demolition being undertaken. 
(g)  Nothing contained in this chapter shall be deemed to prohibit the town from issuing demolition permits where a threat to the public health, safety and welfare exists. 
(Ord. of 1-28-1991) 
Sec. 6-3. - Withholding of approval of building applications when taxes and/or water and/or sewer charges are delinquent. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority granted by G.S. § 7-148(c)(2), as amended, and except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, no application for a building permit, new or repair sewage disposal permit, or well permit shall be approved unless the applicant presents to the official who is to act upon said application a certificate of the collector of revenue stating that any taxes and water and sewer assessments, rates and use charges then due on the premises for which the application is made are not delinquent. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "building permit" shall include the following: building, demolition, electrical, mechanical, plumbing, and security permits. 
(c)  If it is the judgment of the official who is to act upon said application for a building permit, new or repair sewage disposal permit, or well permit, that the interests of public health, safety, or welfare will be better served by the issuance of the permit notwithstanding the applicant's failure to produce the aforesaid certificate from the collector of revenue, then said official may issue said permit, provided all other requirements are met. 
(d)  Where an application for a building permit, new or repair sewage disposal permit, or well permit has been denied on the sole basis that applicant has failed to produce the aforesaid certificate from the collector of revenue, said applicant may appeal said denial to the board of selectmen provided the following conditions are met: Applicant must submit a letter of appeal in writing to the first selectman within ten calendar days of the denial by the official. Said letter of appeal shall set forth the specific reasons why applicant's permit application should be granted notwithstanding applicant's failure to produce the certificate from the collector of revenue. Upon timely submission of the letter of appeal, the first selectman shall schedule said appeal for determination by the board of selectmen at a duly noticed meeting. The applicant shall be notified in writing of the date on which the appeal will be considered by the board of selectmen. It shall be entirely within the discretion of the board of selectmen whether to allow the applicant or others to make a presentation prior to a decision upon said appeal. The board of selectmen shall not be required to decide upon any appeal involving the same or substantially the same matter for a period of one year after its decision upon said earlier request. 
(e)  Where an application for a building permit, new or repair sewage disposal permit, or well permit has been denied for any reason other than or in addition to applicant's failure to produce the aforesaid certificate from the collector of revenue, applicant shall have no right of appeal to the board of selectmen. 
(Ord. of 2-24-1999) 
Chapter 7 - EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 8; police, ch. 15. 
State Law reference- Civil preparedness, G.S. § 28-1 et seq.; local organizations for civil preparedness, G.S. § 28-7. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Emergency dispatch center. 
(a)  The board of selectmen shall have the responsibility for and control over any and all emergency dispatch system or systems to be established and maintained by the town. 
(b)  The board of selectmen shall make, promulgate and amend such rules and regulations for the establishment, operation, staffing and maintenance of the emergency dispatch system as it deems necessary and convenient including, but not limited to, the establishment and collection of fees, rentals and other charges as may be required. 
(Ord. of 6-28-1978(1)) 
Secs. 7-2-7-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CIVIL PREPAREDNESS AGENCY 

Sec. 7-21. - Director; organizational subdivisions. 
    The civil preparedness agency of the town shall be under the supervision and direction of a director appointed by the first selectman. With reasonable conformance to applicable federal and state statutes, the director shall organize the agency into such subdivisions as may be necessary for the efficient conduct of the business of the agency. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(1)) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-31. 
Sec. 7-22. - Advisory council. 
    There shall be a civil preparedness advisory council appointed by the first selectman to advise him in civil preparedness matters and policy. The council members shall serve for two years concurrent with the terms of office of the members of the board of selectmen. The advisory council shall be composed of the police chief, fire chief, superintendent of schools, superintendent of highways and five citizens of the town, one of whom shall serve a chairman of the council. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(1)) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-91 et seq. 
Sec. 7-23. - General responsibility. 
    The civil preparedness agency shall be responsible for the development and maintenance of current plans and programs that may be needed in response to an emergency caused by enemy attack upon this country of any natural or manmade disaster. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(1)) 
Sec. 7-24. - Equipment, supplies. 
    The civil preparedness agency is empowered, subject to the budget appropriated by the town, to obtain needed equipment and supplies to fulfill its responsibilities. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(1)) 
Sec. 7-25. - Emergency situations-First selectman. 
    In an emergency situation the first selectman shall be in full charge of all town personnel and equipment, and the director of civil preparedness shall act as his advisor and chief of staff in directing the town's emergency response activities. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(1)) 
Sec. 7-26. - Same-Declaration. 
    The first selectman may declare a state of emergency for the town if in his opinion such a declaration is necessary. He shall file such declaration with the town clerk and it will be effective for up to 30 days unless voided earlier by the first selectman or action by the board of selectmen. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(1)) 
Sec. 7-27. - Same-Disaster assistance. 
    In a disaster situation, the first selectman is empowered to apply to the state and also through the state to federal agencies for any appropriate disaster assistance that may be made available. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(1)) 
Chapter 8 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; emergency preparedness, ch. 7; housing, ch. 10; police, ch. 15; fire protection codes, § 10-131. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to provide for fire protection, G.S. § 7-148(c)(4)(B); municipal police and fire protection, G.S. § 7-274 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - WATER RESERVOIRS 

Sec. 8-1. - Fire department water reservoir installation requirements. 
    The following is a summary of the Portland Fire Department's requirements for the installation of new or upgraded underground water storage tanks and more accurately defines the requirements of the fire department and only applies to the use of underground water sources. 
    The fire marshal, fire chief and public works director shall review all sub-division applications to determine compliance with this section. Any suggested changes that may modify the requirements listed in this section based on the proximity, availability and accessibility of other water sources shall be presented to the board of selectmen who shall be authorized to make a decision on the application. 
    Subdividers must provide emergency water reservoirs as follows: 
10-40 lots: One 10,000-gallon tank 
41-80 lots: Two 10,000-gallon tanks 
81- 120 lots: Three 10,000-gallon tanks 
Above 120 lots, one additional tank for every 40 lots 
(1)  The minimum capacity of each tank shall be 10,000 gallons or larger by order of the fire chief. 
(2)  The fire department shall determine the best location of the tank. 
(3)  Sand bedding and back fill shall be used on all tank installations. 
(4)  All tanks shall be hydrostatically tested and coated to NFPA 22 standards. 
(5)  The finished height of the drafting pipe shall be 24-inches above the finished roadway surface, measuring from the centerline of the five-inch female Storz connection (Note: This is not the distance above grade at the pipe). 
(6)  The drafting pipe shall extend to within six inches of the bottom of the tank. The total length of the drafting pipe shall be kept to a minimum after meeting item (1). The drafting pipe must be six inches in diameter and terminate with a six-inch 45 degree elbow and accept a six-inch female Fire Thread Swivel Connection with plug and chain. 
(7)  A screened four-inch diameter vent pipe, two elbows or one 180-degree bend with the opening facing downward shall be included on all tanks. 
(8)  A four-inch diameter fill pipe shall be provided on each tank which shall terminate with an elbow to accept a two and one-half-inch female fire thread connection with protective cap and chains. 
(9)  The maximum distance from the road edge to the drafting pipe shall not exceed eight feet. This will allow the fire apparatus to position on the road surface, and easily start a draft using one standard length of hard suction 
(10)  All above ground piping shall be primed and painted as follows: 
a. Red: 6-inch drafting pipe 
b. White: 4-inch vent pipe 
c. Yellow: Fill pipe 
(11)  The Town of Portland shall provide "NO PARKING" signs to be installed at the sight by the installer. 
(12)  The top of all tanks shall be four feet below the finish grade to prevent freezing 
(13)  A 48-hour notification of inspection must be given to the public works director, fire marshal, and fire chief. Approvals of new or upgraded installation must be approved by the same. 
(14)  Tanks shall be filled by the Portland Fire Department after inspection and approval. Any mutual aid company may use the tank but must refill it after use. Notification of usage must be made to the fire chief's office as soon as possible but in no case shall exceed seven days past the date of useage. 
(15)  This document and all other supporting documents shall be provided to the developer and installer prior to any work being performed. It is the installer's responsibility to understand this document and all other specifications. This is not an engineering specification. 
(Ord. of 4-25-2007; Ord. of 11-22-2011) 
Secs. 8-2-8-9. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BULK PROPANE STORAGE 

Sec. 8-10. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to promote and protect the public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the town and to protect other individuals who may be employed, commute through, or visit the town, who may be adversely affected by a catastrophic occurrence or other accident associated with bulk propane storage within the town. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2009, § 8-10) 
Sec. 8-11. - Terms. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bulk means greater than 2,000 gallons of propane. 
    Location means any single lot or property either partially or wholly located within the town, or any lots or properties with at least one common boundary owned by the same owner, that is not directly served by the town municipal water system or have a hydrant connected to the town municipal water supply on or adjacent to such property. The term "location" includes all lots or properties having a boundary contiguous to a property with a residential dwelling located on it or a boundary contiguous to a residential zone. 
    Storage means keeping or maintaining propane at a location through the use of methods including, but not limited to, a tank, truck or any other container for the purpose of sale or distribution. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2009, § 8-11) 
Sec. 8-12. - General prohibition. 
    Bulk propane storage shall be prohibited in any location as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2009, § 8-12) 
Sec. 8-13. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Preexisting bulk propane storage. This article shall prohibit bulk propane storage which did not lawfully exist prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. However, any bulk propane storage lawfully existing prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall not be prohibited and may lawfully continue, including repair and replacement of tanks or containers as may be necessary, provided that any lawfully existing bulk propane storage shall not be increased or expanded after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(b)  Delivery vehicles. Any vehicle, boat or container otherwise lawful and used for delivery of propane to any facility shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2009, § 8-13) 
Sec. 8-14. - Severability and savings clause. 
    In the event that any part or provision of this article is declared to be invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such declaration shall not affect the validity of any other part or provision of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2009, § 8-14) 
Chapter 9 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Housing, ch. 10; solid waste management, ch. 16; sewers, § 20-21 et seq. 
State Law reference- Public health and safety, G.S. title 19; public health and well-being, G.S. title 19a. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Litter on highways. 
    Any person throwing or placing waste materials or paper on the highways of the town shall be guilty of a violation and subject to arrest and a fine in accordance with section 1-11. When waste material and/or paper is thrown from a motor vehicle, the operator thereof shall be deemed prima facie to have violated this section and be subject to the above penalty. 
(Ord. of 6-30-1960) 
Secs. 9-2-9-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Uniform Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, G.S. § 21a-13 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized representative means the person making quarterly inspections of all service establishments and restaurants who reports directly to the director. 
    Director of health means the director of health for the town. 
    Food means any raw, cooked, or processed edible substance, beverage or ingredient (including ice) used or intended for use, in whole or in part, for human consumption. 
    Food establishment means any vehicle or place where food or beverage intended for human consumption is manufactured, prepared, stored, offered for sale, sold or served. 
    Food service establishment means any place where food or beverage is prepared or served, with or without charge, for consumption on or off the premises including catering establishments or any eating place whether fixed or mobile. The term does not include a private home where food is prepared for individual family consumption, and it does not include the location of food vending machines. 
    Food-vending machine means a device automatically operated to supply food without the direct supervision of a human being. 
    Temporary food establishment means any place dispensing food and/or beverage for a period of time not to exceed 14 days. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 9-22. - Toilet facilities. 
(a)  All new or extensively altered food service establishments shall provide adequate separate male and female toilet room facilities for the public, which would include adequate toilets, urinals, handwashing sinks with hot and cold or tempered running water, hand cleansing soap or detergent, approved sanitary towels or other approved hand drying device, and receptacles for waste materials. 
(b)  The entrances to toilet rooms shall be equipped with tight-fitting self-closing doors, and shall be so arranged as to prevent direct view of the interior when the exterior doors are open. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 10) 
Sec. 9-23. - Submission of plans. 
(a)  Whenever a food service establishment is constructed or remodeled and whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a food service establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling, or alteration shall be submitted to the director of health, or his authorized agent, for review and approval 30 days prior to issuing a food service license or a building permit, and before construction, remodeling or alteration is begun. 
(b)  The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed layout, arrangement, and construction materials of work areas, and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. 
(c)  The director of health, or his authorized agent, shall approve the plans and specifications if they meet the requirements of this article, the state public health code, and any other applicable statutes, ordinances or rules and regulations. No food service establishment shall be constructed, remodeled, or altered except in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the director of health, or his authorized agent. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 11) 
Sec. 9-24. - Preoperation inspection. 
    Whenever plans and specifications are required by section 9-23 to be submitted to the director of health, or his authorized agent, the director of health, or his authorized agent, shall inspect the food service establishment prior to its beginning operation to determine compliance with the approved plans and specifications, and with the requirements of this article and the state public health code. Access by the health officer or certified inspector for routine inspections is a condition of the license. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 12) 
Sec. 9-25. - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article and/or the state public health code shall be guilty of a violation and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in accordance with section 1-11. In addition thereto, such person may be enjoined from continuing such violations. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 13) 
Secs. 9-26-9-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, ch. 11. 

Sec. 9-41. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a food service establishment or offer its services within the town who does not have a valid license issued to him by the director of health. Only a person who complies with the requirements of this article and the state public health code shall be entitled to receive or retain such a license. Licenses are not transferable. A valid license shall be posted in every food service establishment. Licenses for temporary food services establishments shall be issued for a period of time not to exceed 14 consecutive days. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 2) 
Sec. 9-42. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate a food service establishment shall, at least ten days prior to the opening or change of ownership of such establishment, make written application for a license on forms provided by the director of health. Such application shall include, but not be limited to, the name and address of each applicant, the location and type of the proposed food service establishment, and the signature of each applicant. If the application is for a temporary food service establishment, it shall also include the dates of the proposed operation and the name of the person responsible. 
(b)  The application shall be accompanied by the appropriate fee and a set of plans of the food service establishment as required by section 9-23. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 3(a), (b)) 
Sec. 9-43. - Inspection, issuance. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of final approval for a license, the director of health, or his authorized agent, shall inspect the proposed food service establishment to determine compliance with the provisions of this article, the state public health code, and any other applicable statutes, ordinances, or rules and regulations. 
(b)  The director of health shall issue a license to the applicant if the inspection reveals that the proposed food services establishment complies with the requirements of this article, the state public health code, and any other applicable statutes, ordinances or rules and regulations. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 3(c), (d)) 
Sec. 9-44. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be a flat fee for every establishment, which shall be set from time to time, and a schedule of such fee is on file in the town clerk's office. The board of selectmen shall be authorized to alter such fee upward or downward after public hearing. Public schools and tax-exempt churches and other organizations shall be exempt from payment of such fee, but must obtain a license. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 4) 
Sec. 9-45. - Expiration. 
    All licenses issued under the provisions of this division shall expire one year after the date of issuance, unless otherwise indicated, and may be renewed for another year upon application and payment of the annual fee, provided the food service establishment is in compliance with this article, the state public health code, and any other applicable statutes, ordinances or rules and regulations. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 5) 
Sec. 9-46. - Suspension. 
(a)  The director of health may suspend any license to operate a food service establishment if the license holder does not comply with the requirements of this article or the state public health code. If the director of health finds unsanitary or other conditions in the operation of a food service establishment which, in his judgment, constitute an immediate and substantial hazard to public health, he may immediately issue a written notice to the license holder or operator citing such conditions, specifying the corrective action to be taken and if necessary, order immediate corrections. Such written notice shall indicate his intention to suspend the license. If correction is not made in the stated time, the license shall be suspended. Suspension is effective upon service of a notice as stated in section 9-49. When a license is suspended, food service operations shall immediately cease. 
(b)  Whenever a license is suspended, the license holder or person in charge may, within 48 hours, file a written appeal with the director of health. If no appeal is filed within 48 hours, the suspension becomes final. If an appeal is filed, the director of health shall thereupon immediately examine into the merits of such suspension and may vacate, modify or affirm such suspension. 
(c)  During the process of appeal, the license shall remain suspended. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 6) 
Sec. 9-47. - Revocation. 
(a)  The director of health may, after providing opportunity for an appeal and hearing, revoke a license for serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of this article or the state public health code, or for interference with the director of health, or his authorized agent, in the performance of their duties. Prior to revocation, the director of health shall notify the license holder or person in charge, in writing, of the reasons for which the license is subject to revocation, and that the license shall be revoked at the end of 14 days following service of such notice, unless an appeal is filed with the director of health by the license holder within 48 hours. If no request for appeal is filed within 48 hours, the revocation of the license becomes final. If an appeal is filed, the director of health shall thereupon immediately examine the merits of such revocation and may vacate, modify or affirm such revocation. 
(b)  During the process of appeal, the license shall remain revoked. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 7) 
Sec. 9-48. - Reinstatement. 
(a)  Suspension. Whenever a license issued under this division has been suspended, the holder of the suspended license may make a written request for reinstatement of the suspended license. Within ten days following receipt of a written request, including a statement signed by the applicant that, in his opinion, the conditions causing the suspension have been corrected, the director of health, or his authorized agent, shall make a reinspection. If the applicant is complying with the requirements of this article, the state public health code, and any other applicable statutes ordinances or rules and regulations, the license will be reinstated. 
(b)  Revocation. When the establishment complies with this article, the state public health code, and any other applicable statutes, ordinances or rules and regulations, a written application may be made for the reinstatement of a license, as provided in section 9-42, and payment of the annual fee. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 9) 
Sec. 9-49. - Service of notices. 
    A notice provided for in this article is properly served when it is delivered to the license holder or person in charge, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the license holder. A copy of any notice and proof of service thereof shall be filed in the records of the director of health. 
(Ord. of 6-21-1979(2), § 8) 
Chapter 10 - HOUSING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, ch. 8; health and sanitation, ch. 9; planning, ch. 14; utilities, ch. 20; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to make rules relating to the maintenance of safe and sanitary housing, G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(A)(i); creation of housing authorities, G.S. § 8-40; powers of housing authorities, G.S. § 8-44. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Purpose. 
    It is hereby declared that the purpose of this chapter is to protect, preserve, and promote the physical and mental health and social well-being of the people, to investigate and control incidences of communicable diseases, to regulate privately and publicly owned dwellings for the purpose of maintaining adequate sanitation and public health, and to protect the safety of the people and to promote the general welfare by legislation which shall be applicable to all dwellings now in existence or hereafter constructed. It is hereby further declared that the purpose of this chapter is to: 
(1)  Establish minimum standards for basic equipment and facilities for light, ventilation, heating and cooling, for safety from fire and accidents, for the use and location and amount of space for human occupancy, and for safe and sanitary maintenance; 
(2)  Determine the responsibilities of owners, operators and occupants of dwellings; and 
(3)  Provide for the administration and enforcement thereof. 
(Ord. of 10-5-1967, § 1.01) 
Sec. 10-2. - Legislative finding. 
    It is hereby found that premises exist within the town which are blighted because there exists thereon blighted buildings or other structures, either occupied or unoccupied by human beings, and such buildings or other structures are blighted because of faulty design or construction, or failure to keep them in a proper state of repair, or lack of proper sanitary facilities, or lack of adequate lighting or ventilation, or inability to properly heat or cool, or improper management, or any combination of these factors which has resulted in such buildings or structures becoming so deteriorated, so dilapidated, so neglected, so overcrowded with occupants, or so insanitary as to jeopardize or be detrimental to the health, safety, morals, or welfare of the people of the city. It is hereby further found that such blighted premises and such blighted buildings or other structures contribute to the development of, or increase in physical, mental or social ill-health, or disease and mortality, crime and juvenile delinquency. It is hereby further found that conditions existing on such blighted premises are dangerous to the public health, safety, morals, and general welfare of the people; and that conditions existing on such blighted premises necessitate excessive and disproportionate expenditure of public funds for public health, public safety, crime prevention, fire protection and other public services; that the conditions existing on such blighted premises cause a drain upon public revenue and impair the efficient and economical exercise of governmental function in such areas. It is hereby further found that the elimination of blighted premises and the prevention of occurrence of blighted premises in the future are in the best interests of the public. The accomplishment of this end will be fostered and encouraged by the enactment and enforcement of this chapter. The enactment and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter is hereby declared to be liberally construed to effectuate the purposes as stated heretofore in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 10-5-1967, § 1.02) 
Sec. 10-3. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the housing code. 
(Ord. of 10-5-1967, § 1.03) 
Sec. 10-4. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory structure means a detached structure which is not used or not intended to be used for living or sleeping by human occupants and which is located on the same premises. 
    Approved means approved by the local or state authority having such administrative authority. 
    Ashes means the residue from the burning of combustible materials and the noncombustible portion of the refuse charged into an incinerator. 
    Central heating system means a single system supplying heat to one or more dwelling units or more than one rooming units. 
    Dwelling means any enclosed space which is wholly or partly used or intended to be used for living or sleeping by human occupants; provided that temporary housing as hereinafter defined shall not be regarded as a dwelling. 
    Dwelling unit means any room or group of rooms located within a dwelling and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    Enforcing officer means the official charged with the administration and enforcement of this chapter, or his regularly authorized representative. 
    Extermination means the control and elimination of insects, rodents, or other pests by eliminating their harborage places; by removing or making inaccessible materials that may serve as their food; by poisoning, spraying, fumigating, trapping, or by any other recognized and legal pest elimination methods approved by the health officer. 
    Family means one adult person plus or more persons who are legally related to said person and residing in the same dwelling unit with said person. 
    Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, serving, and nonconsumption of food, and any animal waste or offal. 
    Guest means any person who shares a dwelling unit in a non-permanent status for not more than 30 days. 
    Habitable room means a room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking, or eating purposes, excluding bathrooms, water closet compartments, laundries, furnace rooms, pantries, kitchenettes and utility rooms of less than 50 square feet, foyers, or communicating corridors, stairways, closets, storage spaces, and workshops, hobby and recreation areas in unsealed or uninsulated parts of structure below ground level or in attics. 
    Health officer means the legally designated health authority of the town or his authorized representative. 
    Heated water means water heated to a temperature of not less than 120 degrees Fahrenheit. 
    Household means a family or one or more unrelated persons, including servants and not more than two boarders, who share the same dwelling and use some or all of its cooking and eating facilities. 
    Infestation means the presence within or around a dwelling of any insects, rodents or other pests. 
    Kitchen means any room containing any or all of the following equipment; or area of a room within three feet of such equipment; sink or other device for dishwashing, stove or other device for cooking, refrigerator or other device for cool storage of food. 
    Meaning of certain words. Whenever the words "dwelling," "dwelling unit," "rooming house," "rooming unit," "premises," "structure" are used in this chapter, they shall be construed as though they were followed by the words "or any part thereof." Words used in the singular include the plural, and the plural the singular, the masculine gender includes the feminine and the feminine the masculine. 
    Multiple dwelling means any dwelling containing more than two dwelling units. 
    Occupant means any person, over one year of age, living, sleeping, cooking, or eating in, or actually having possession of, a dwelling unit or a rooming unit; except that in dwelling units a guest will not be considered an occupant. 
    Operator means any person who has charge, care or control of a building, or part thereof, in which dwelling units or rooming units are let. 
    Ordinary winter conditions means a temperature 15 degrees Fahrenheit above the lowest recorded temperature in the locality for the prior ten-year period. 
    Owner means any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others: 
(1)  Shall have legal title to any dwelling or dwelling unit, with or without accompanying actual possession thereof; or 
(2)  Shall have charge, care, or control of any dwelling or dwelling unit, as owner or agent of the owner. Any such person thus representing the actual owner shall be bound to comply with the provisions of this chapter and of rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, to the same extent as if he were the owner. 
    Permissible occupancy means the maximum number of persons permitted as family or household to reside in a dwelling unit or rooming unit based on the square foot per person in habitable rooms. 
    Plumbing means and includes all of the following supplied facilities and equipment: gas pipes, gas burning equipment, water pipes, garbage disposal units, waste pipes, water closets, sinks, installed dishwashers, lavatories, bathtubs, shower baths, installed clothes washing machines, catch basins, drains, vents, and any other similar supplied fixtures, together with all connections to water, sewer, septic tank or gas lines. 
    Premises means a platted lot or part thereof or unplatted lot or parcel of land or plot of land, either occupied or unoccupied by any dwelling or nondwelling structure and includes any such building, accessory structure or other structure thereon. 
    Privacy means the ability of a person or persons to carry out an activity commenced without interruption or interference, either by sight or sound, by unwanted persons. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solids (except body wastes) including garbage, rubbish, ashes and dead animals. 
    Rooming house means any dwelling or that part of any dwelling containing one or more rooming units, in which space is occupied by three or more persons who are not members of a single family. 
    Rooming unit means any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable unit used or intended to be used for living and sleeping, but not for cooking or eating purposes. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes (excluding ashes) consisting of both: 
(1)  Combustible wastes such as paper, cardboard, plastic containers, yard clippings, and wood; and 
(2)  Noncombustible wastes such as tin cans, glass and crockery. 
    Safety means the condition of being free from danger and hazards which may cause accidents or disease. 
    Septic tank means a receptacle, usually underground, to which sewage is drained and retained to effect disintegration of the organic matter by bacteria. 
    Space heater means a self-contained, automatically controlled, vented fuel-burning appliance of either the circulating type or the radiant type. 
    Supplied means paid for, furnished, provided by, or under the control of the owner or operator. 
    Temporary housing means any tent, trailer, mobile home, or any other structure used for human shelter which is designed to be transportable and is not attached to the ground, to another structure, or to any utility system on the same premises for more than 30 consecutive days. 
(Ord. of 10-5-1967, §§ 2.01-2.37) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-5. - Liability of officials. 
    The enforcing officer and his assistants shall be free from personal liability for acts done in good faith in the performance of official duties. 
(Ord. of 10-5-1967, § 17.03) 
Sec. 10-6. - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall willfully refuse or fail to obey an order of the housing code board of appeals to meet the minimum standards of this chapter or of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than $10.00 nor more than $100.00, or be imprisoned not less than five days nor more than 30 days. Each day's failure to comply shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. of 10-5-1967, § 15.01) 
Secs. 10-7-10-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNERS AND OCCUPANTS 

Sec. 10-21. - Dwellings and premises to be clean, sanitary and fit before occupancy.
