Doors, curtains, blinds and/or other closures installed in or on the entrances and/or exits of such booths, cubicles, studios and rooms which are closed while said areas are in use encourage patrons using said areas to engage in sexual acts therein with prostitutes or others, thereby promoting and encouraging prostitution and the commission of sexual acts which cause blood, semen and urine to be deposited on the floors and/or walls of said areas, which deposits could prove detrimental to the health and safety of other persons who may come into contact with such deposits. 
f.  The reasonable regulation and supervision of such adult-oriented establishments tends to discourage such sexual acts and prostitution and thereby promotes the health, safety and welfare of the patrons, clients and customers of such establishments. 
g.  The nature of adult-oriented establishments and the traffic which they generate and the potential and the propensity for such establishments to attract persons interested in explicit sexual activities or erotic art forms and the potential for outdoor assembly of such persons around the premises of such establishments are such as to make them incompatible with nearby uses of land where concentrations of children or youth tend to congregate. 
(3)  The continued unregulated operation of adult-oriented establishments, including without limitations those specifically cited in subsection (1) hereof, is and would be detrimental to the general welfare, health and safety of the citizens of the town. 
(4)  The constitution and laws of the state grant to the town powers, especially police power, to enact reasonable legislation and measures to regulate and supervise adult-oriented establishments as hereinafter defined in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(5)  It is not the intent of the board of selectmen, in enacting this article, to deny to any person rights to speech protected by the United States and/or state Constitutions nor is it the intent of the board of selectmen to impose any additional limitations or restrictions on the contents or any communicative materials, including sexually oriented films, videotapes, books and/or other materials. Further, by enacting this article, the board of selectmen does not intend to deny or restrict the rights of any adult to obtain and/or view any sexually oriented materials protected by the United States and/or state Constitutions nor does it intend to restrict or deny any constitutionally protected rights that distributors or exhibitors of such sexually oriented materials may have to sell, distribute or exhibit such materials. 
(Ord. of 5-13-1998, § 1) 
Sec. 12-32. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the words and phrases used herein shall have the following meanings, unless otherwise clearly indicated by the context: 
    Adult amusement machine means any amusement machine that is regularly used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities and specified anatomical areas, as defined below, for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult bookstore means an establishment having any portion of its stock and trade in books, films, videocassettes or magazines and other periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined below, provided that this definition shall not apply to any establishment in which such materials constitute less than ten percent of the value of the inventory of said establishment and in which the display of such materials does not permit the viewing of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas within the establishment. 
    Adult entertainment means any exhibition of any adult-oriented motion pictures, live performance, display or dance of any type, removal of articles of clothing or appearing unclothed, pantomime, modeling or any other personal services offered to customers, which has as a significant or substantial portion of such performance or any actual or simulated performance of specified sexual activities or exhibition and viewing of specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult mini-motion-picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of less than 50 persons regularly used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined below, for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult motion-picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of 50 or more persons regularly used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined below, for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult-oriented establishment includes, without limitation, adult bookstores, adult motion-picture theaters, adult mini-motion-picture theaters and commercial establishments containing one or more adult amusement machines. "Adult-oriented establishment" further means any premises to which the public, patrons or members are invited or admitted and which are so physically arranged as to provide booths, cubicles, rooms, studios, compartments or stalls separate from the common areas of the premises for the purpose of viewing adult-oriented motion pictures, or any premises wherein an entertainer provides adult entertainment to a member of the public, a patron or a member when such adult entertainment is held, conducted, operated or maintained for a profit, direct or indirect. An "adult-oriented establishment" further includes, without limitation, any adult entertainment studio or any premises that are physically arranged and used as such, whether advertised or represented as an adult entertainment studio, rap studio, exotic dance studio, encounter studio, sensitivity studio, modeling studio or any other term of like import. 
    Amusement machine means any machine which, upon the payment of a charge or upon insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disk, may be operated by the public for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a score and whether or not electronically operated. 
    Board of selectmen means the board of selectmen of the Town of Portland, Connecticut. 
    Employee means any and all persons, including independent contractors, who work in or at or render any services directly related to the operation of an adult-oriented establishment. 
    Entertainer means any person who provides entertainment within an adult-oriented establishment as defined in this section, whether or not a fee is charged or accepted for entertainment and whether or not entertainment is provided as an employee or an independent contractor. 
    Inspector means a police officer of the town and/or an employee of the town designated by the first selectman, who shall hereby be authorized to inspect premises regulated under this article and to take the required actions authorized by this article in case of violations being found on such premises and to require corrections of unsatisfactory conditions found on said premises. 
    Minor means a person under the age of 18 years. 
    Operator means any person or any proprietor, shareholder, general partner or limited partner who holds any share or partnership interest of any business which is operating, conducting, owning or maintaining an adult-oriented establishment. 
    Specified anatomical areas: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic region, buttocks and female breasts below a point immediately above the top of the areola. 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state even if completely covered. 
    Specified sexual activities: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal. 
(2)  Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy. 
(3)  Fondling or erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock or female breasts. 
This definition is not intended to include any medical publications or films or bona fide educational publication or films, nor does it include any art or photography publications which devote at least 25 percent of the lineage of each issue to articles and advertisements dealing with subjects or art or photograph, nor does this definition apply to any news periodical which reports or describes current events and which, from time to time, publishes photographs of nude or seminude persons in connection with the dissemination of the news, nor does this definition apply to publications or films which describe and report different cultures and which, from time to time, publish or show photographs or depictions of nude or seminude persons when describing cultures in which nudity or seminudity is indigenous to the population. 
(Ord. of 5-13-1998, § 2) 
Sec. 12-33. - Requirements for adult-oriented establishments. 
(a)  No operator or employee of an adult-oriented establishment shall allow or permit any minor or intoxicated person to loiter in any part of such establishment, including parking lots immediately adjacent to such establishment used by patrons of such adult-oriented establishment. 
(b)  Every adult-oriented establishment shall display a sign outside each entrance bearing the words "Adult-oriented establishment-Persons under 18 not admitted," in letters two inches high. 
(c)  No adult-oriented establishment shall be conducted in such a manner that permits the observation of any material depicting specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas from the outside of the building that houses the adult-oriented establishment. 
(d)  Every adult-oriented establishment doing business in the town in conformance with all applicable zoning, building and health regulations on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, shall be well-lighted at all times and be physically arranged in such a manner that the entire interior portion of the booths, cubicles, rooms or stalls wherein adult entertainment is provided shall be clearly visible from the common areas of the premises. Visibility into such booths, cubicles, rooms or stalls shall not be blocked or obscured by doors, curtains, partitions, drapes, room arrangement or any other obstruction whatsoever. It shall be unlawful to install enclosed booths, cubicles, rooms or stalls within adult-oriented establishments for whatever purpose, but especially for the purpose of providing for the secluded viewing of adult-oriented motion pictures or other types of adult-oriented entertainment. 
(e)  On or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, the operator of each adult-oriented establishment shall be responsible for and shall provide that any room or other area used for the purpose of viewing adult-oriented motion pictures or other types of live adult entertainment shall be well-lighted and readily accessible at all times and shall be continuously open to view in its entirety. The premises shall be equipped with overhead lighting fixtures of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which patrons are permitted access at an illumination of not less than 1.0 footcandle as measured at the floor level. It shall be the duty of the operator and its agents to ensure that the illumination described above is maintained at all times that any patron is present in the premises. 
(f)  Every act or omission by an employee constituting a violation of the provisions of this article shall be deemed the act or omission of the operator if such act or omission occurs either with the authorization, knowledge or approval of the operator or as a result of the operator's negligent failure to supervise the employee's conduct, and the operator shall be punishable for such act or omission in the same manner as if the operator committed the act or caused the omission. 
(g)  An operator shall be responsible for the conduct of all employees while on the licensed premises, and any act or omission of any employee constituting a violation of the provisions of this article shall be deemed the act or omission of the operator for purposes of determining whether the operator shall be subject to the penalties imposed by this article. 
(h)  All adult-oriented establishments shall be open to inspection at all reasonable times by a city inspector or such other person(s) as the board of selectmen may designate. Information regarding employees, including name, date of birth and social security number, must be maintained as part of the record and must be available for inspection by town officials. 
(Ord. of 5-13-1998, § 3) 
Sec. 12-34. - Minimum distances from youth facilities. 
    No adult-oriented establishment shall be located less than 500 feet from any of the following uses if any such uses are existing at the time when the adult-oriented establishment is established: any public or private school serving grade 12 or lower; any day-care center, nursery school or similar use; any public parks or playground, any commercial or not-for-profit outdoor or indoor recreational facility; any church or place of worship; any playground associated with a church or other community building, any public or private hospital and/or center for treatment of psychiatric, psychological, or chemical dependency disorders, which hospital or center teats minors; any residential zone. Measurements of distance shall be from the closest property line of the adult-oriented establishment to the closest property line of such school, day-care center, nursery school or similar use, public park or playground, church or place of worship, church or community playground, hospital, or any parcel being residentially zoned. The separating distance required by this section shall be determined as of the date that any adult-oriented establishment commences to operate in accordance with this article and any applicable provision(s) of the town zoning regulations, building code, health code and other applicable state and local laws, and such adult-oriented establishment shall not be deemed to violate this section if thereafter one of the enumerated uses is established within the distance set forth herein. 
(Ord. of 5-13-1998, § 4; Ord. of 11-28-2007) 
Sec. 12-35. - Minimum distances from other adult-oriented establishments. 
    No adult-oriented establishments shall be located less than 1,000 feet from any existing adult-oriented establishment. Measurements of distances shall be from the closest property line of the proposed adult-oriented establishment to the closest property line of the existing adult-oriented establishment. 
(Ord. of 5-13-1998, § 5) 
Sec. 12-36. - Exemptions for preexisting uses. 
    The provisions of the preceding sections 12-34 and 12-35 shall not be deemed to prohibit any use lawfully preexisting the effective date of this article. Any preexisting use which shall be discontinued for a period of 30 days shall thereafter conform to sections 12-34 and 12-35. 
(Ord. of 5-13-1998, § 6) 
Sec. 12-37. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person, partnership or corporation who is found to have violated this article shall be fined a definite sum not exceeding $100.00 for each such violation. 
(b)  Each violation of this article shall be considered a separate offense, and any violation continuing more than one hour of time shall be considered a separate offense for each hour of violation. 
(Ord. of 5-13-1998, § 7) 
Secs. 12-38, 12-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE 

Sec. 12-40. - Declaration of policy. 
    Excessive noise must be controlled by the town to protect, preserve and promote the public health, safety and welfare. The board of selectmen recognizes the fact that people have the right to and should be ensured an environment free from excessive sound and vibration that may jeopardize their health, safety or welfare. 
(Ord. of 9-26-2001) 
Sec. 12-41. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings hereinafter set out: 
    Background noise. Noise that exists at a point as a result of the combination of many distant sources, individually indistinguishable. 
    Construction. The assembly, erection, substantial repair, alteration, demolition or site-preparation for or of public or private rights-of-way, buildings or other structures, utilities or property. 
    Daytime hours. The hours between 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., local time. 
    Decibel. A unit of measurement of the sound level, the symbol for which is dB. 
    Emergency. Any occurrence or set of circumstances involving actual or imminent physical trauma or property damage which demands immediate action. 
    Excessive noise. Any sound, the intensity of which exceeds the standards set forth in section 12-45 of this chapter. 
    First selectman. The duly elected first selectman of the town or his designee. 
    Impulse noise. Sound of short duration, usually less than one second, with an abrupt onset and rapid decay. 
    Intrusion alarm. A device with an audible signal which, when activated, indicates intrusion by an unauthorized person. 
    Motor vehicle. A vehicle as defined in G.S. § 14-1(30), Revision of 1958, as amended. 
    Nighttime hours. The hours between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., local time. 
    Noise level. A frequency-weighted sound pressure level as measured with a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. The level so read is designated dBA. 
    Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, association, syndicate, company, trust, corporation, municipality, agency or political or administrative subdivision of the state or other entity of any kind. 
    Premises. Any building, structure, land or portion thereof, including all appurtenances, owned or controlled by a person. 
    Property maintenance equipment. All engine or motor powered tools and equipment used occasionally in the repair and upkeep of exterior property and including, but not limited to, lawn mowers, riding tractors, wood chippers, power saws and leaf blowers. 
    Public emergency sound signal. A device, either stationary or mobile, producing audible signals associated with a set of circumstances involving actual or imminent danger to persons or damage to property which demands immediate action. 
    Public facility maintenance. All activity related to the clearing, cleaning, repair and upkeep of public roads, sidewalks, sewers, water mains, utilities and publicly owned property. 
    Recreation vehicle. Any non-registered combustion engine powered vehicle which is being used for recreational purposes. 
    Sound. A transmission of energy through solid, liquid or gaseous media in the form of vibrations which constitute alterations in pressure or position of the particles in the medium and which, in air, evoke physiological sensations, including, but not limited to, an auditory response when impinging on the ear. 
    Sound level meter. An instrument used to measure sound levels. A sound level meter shall conform, as a minimum, to the American National Standards Institute's operational specifications for sound level meters SI.4-1983 (Type 2). 
    Sound pressure level. 20 times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of the pressure of a sound to the reference pressure of 20 micronewtons per square meter (20 × 10-6 Newtons/M 2 ) and is expressed in decibel (dB). 
(Ord. of 9-26-2001) 
Sec. 12-42. - Applicability. 
    This chapter shall not apply to noise emitted by or related to: 
(1)  Natural phenomena. 
(2)  The unamplified sound made by any wild animal. 
(3)  A bell or chime from any building clock, school or church. 
(4)  A public emergency sound signal. 
(5)  Farming equipment or farming activity. 
(6)  An emergency. 
(7)  Snow removal equipment, provided that such equipment shall be maintained in good repair so as to minimize noise and noise discharge from exhausts shall be adequately muffled to prevent loud and/or explosive noises. 
(8)  Unamplified human voice. 
(Ord. of 9-26-2001) 
Sec. 12-43. - Exemptions. 
    The following shall be exempt from this chapter, subject to the special conditions noted: 
(1)  Noise generated by engine-powered or motor-driven lawn care or maintenance equipment shall be exempted between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., provided that noise discharged from exhausts is adequately muffled to prevent loud and/or explosive noises therefrom. 
(2)  Noise generated by any construction equipment operated during daytime hours. 
(3)  Noise created by any recreational activities that are sanctioned by the town, including, but not limited to, parades, sporting events, concerts and firework displays. 
(4)  Noise created by blasting, provided that the blasting is conducted between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. local time, and provided that a permit for such blasting has been obtained from state or local authorities. 
(5)  Noise created by refuse and solid waste collection, provided that such activity is conducted between 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(6)  Noise created by a fire or intrusion alarm which, from time of activation of the audible signal, emits noise for a period of time not exceeding ten minutes when such alarm is attached to a vehicle or 30 minutes when attached to any building or structure. The repetition of activation of the audible signal of an intrusion alarm due to malfunction, lack of proper maintenance or lack of reasonable care shall be considered excessive noise. 
(7)  Noise created by public facility maintenance. 
(8)  Agricultural and golf course uses. 
(Ord. of 9-26-2001) 
Sec. 12-44. - Noise level measurement procedures. 
    For the purpose of determining noise levels as set forth in this chapter, the following guidelines shall be applicable: 
(1)  A person conducting sound measurements shall have been trained in the techniques and principles of sound measuring equipment and instrumentation. 
(2)  Instruments used to determine a sound level measurements shall be sound level meters as defined by this article. 
(3)  The following steps shall be taken when preparing to take sound level measurements: 
a.  The instrument manufacturer's specific instructions for the preparation and use of the instrument shall be followed. 
b.  Measurements to determine compliance with section 12-45 shall be taken at a point that is located more or less one foot beyond the boundary of the emitters premises and within the receptor's premises. 
(Ord. of 9-26-2001) 
Sec. 12-45. - Noise levels. 
(a)  Noise levels. It shall be unlawful for any person to emit or cause to be emitted any noise beyond the boundaries of his premises in excess of the noise levels established in this article. 
(b)  Noise level standards (per state regulations). 
(1)  No person shall emit noise exceeding the levels stated herein: 
Zone in Which Emitter Is 
Located Zone in Which Receptor is Located I, IP, ISM Zone 
(dBA) B1, B2, B3, FP Zone 
(dBA) Residential Zones Daytime Hours 
(dBA) Nighttime Hours 
(dBA) I, IP, ISM 70 66 61 51 B1, B2, B3, FP 62 62 55 45 Residential 62 55 55 45  
(2)  Any use which is nonconforming shall be deemed to be in the zone which corresponds to the actual use. 
(c)  Background noise and impulse noise. 
(1)  In those individual cases where the background noise levels caused by sources not subject to this chapter exceed the standards contained herein, a source shall be considered to cause excessive noise if the noise emitted by such source exceeds the background noise levels by five dBA, provided that no source subject to this chapter shall emit noise in excess of 80 dBA at any time, and provided that this subsection shall not be interpreted as decreasing the noise level standards of this section. 
(2)  No person shall cause or allow the emission of impulse noise in excess of 80 decibels peak sound pressure level during nighttime hours. 
(3)  No person shall cause or allow the emission of impulse noise in excess of 100 decibels peak sound pressure level at any time. 
(d)  Motor vehicle noise. 
(1)  All motor vehicles operated within the limits of the town shall be subject to the noise standards and decibel levels as set forth in the regulations of the state department of motor vehicles, section 14-80a-1a(a-1), entitled "Maximum Permissible Noise Levels for Vehicles." 
(2)  No sound-amplifying devices on or within motor vehicles shall emit noise in excess of the noise levels as specified in this section. 
(e)  Recreational vehicle noise. No person shall create or cause to be created any unreasonably loud or disturbing noise due to the operation of a recreational vehicle. A noise shall be deemed to be unreasonably loud and a violation of this article when the noise so generated exceeds the noise level standards in this section. 
(Ord. of 9-26-2001) 
Sec. 12-46. - Penalties for offenses. 
(a)  Any person in violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an infraction and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $50.00. A police officer shall serve upon a violator an infraction notice which shall be known as a "noise ticket." Payment of the fine prescribed by such noise ticket within the time limit specified thereon shall constitute a plea of nolo contendere and shall save the violator harmless from prosecution for the offense cited. 
(b)  Each day a violation continues after the time for correction of the violation has been given in a ticket shall constitute a continuing violation, and the amount of the fine shall be doubled for each day said violation continues, said fine not to exceed $400.00 per day. 
(Ord. of 9-26-2001) 
Sec. 12-47. - Variances. 
(a)  Any person residing or doing business in town may apply to the first selectman for a variance from one or more of the provisions of this article which are more stringent than the state department of environmental protection's regulations for the control of noise, provided that the applicant supplies all of the following information to the first selectman at least 30 days prior to the start of said activity: 
(1)  The location and nature of activity. 
(2)  The time period and hours of operation of said activity. 
(3)  The nature and intensity of the noise that will be generated. 
(4)  Any other information required by the first selectman. 
(b)  Following receipt and review of an application for a variance, the first selectman shall fix a date, time and location for a hearing on such application to be held within 14 days of receipt and shall cause the applicant to publish at his own expense a notice of the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation and provide personal notification to all abutters of record. Within seven days of the hearing on the variance application, the first selectman shall issue his determination regarding such application. All such decisions shall briefly set forth the reasons for the decision. 
(c)  No variance from these regulations shall be issued unless it has been demonstrated that: 
(1)  The proposed activity will not violate any provisions of the state department of environmental protection regulations. 
(2)  The noise levels generated by the proposed activity will not constitute a danger to the public health. 
(3)  Compliance with this chapter constitutes an unreasonable hardship on the applicant. 
(d)  Failure to rule on the application in the designated time shall constitute approval of the variance. 
(Ord. of 9-26-2001) 
Sec. 12-48. - Interpretation; severability. 
    All provisions of the zoning regulations of the town which are more stringent than those set forth herein shall remain in force. If, for any reason, any word, clause, paragraph or section of this article shall be held to make the same unconstitutional or be superseded by any state law or regulation, this article shall not thereby be invalidated, and the remainder of the article shall continue in effect. 
(Ord. of 9-26-2001) 
Sec. 12-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RESIDENTIAL FALSE ALARM 

Sec. 12-50. - Purpose and intent. 
    The erroneous and mistaken use of burglar and fire alarm systems and those that are not installed, maintained or operated properly has resulted in increased service calls and is creating a hazard to the members of the police and fire departments servicing the town and the general public. The purpose of this section is to regulate the use of said alarm systems and to reduce the incidence of false alarms responded to by the police and fire departments servicing the town. 
(Ord. of 4-24-2002) 
Sec. 12-51. - Definitions. 
    Alarm system: Any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, installed and operating from a residence arranged to transmit a signal to a commercial monitoring service of the occurrence of a fire or police emergency to which fire or police personal are expected to respond. 
    Chief of the department: Chief of the department having jurisdiction or such other officer, as chief of that jurisdiction shall appoint as his designee. 
    Department: The town police department or town fire department. 
    False alarm: 
(1)  Error or mistake: Any action by a residence owning, leasing, operating or controlling an alarm system installed in any dwelling in the town or any action by any agent or employee of, or anyone in privity with, said person, which results in the unintentional activation of said alarm system when no police or fire emergency exists. 
(2)  Malfunction: Any unintentional activation of any alarm system caused by a flaw in design or installation of or the improper maintenance of the system. This shall not include any activation caused by violent conditions of nature or other extraordinary circumstances, not reasonably subject to the control of the residence. 
(3)  Intentional misuse: Any intentional activation of an alarm system when no police or fire emergency exists. 
(Ord. of 4-24-2002) 
Sec. 12-52. - Alarm errors, mistakes or malfunctions; penalty. 
    No alarm system shall be activated by error, mistake or malfunction in any dwelling, building or place when no police or fire emergency exists which results in the response of the department having jurisdiction. 
    The following fines and charges shall be imposed upon the residence for activation of an alarm system by error, mistake or malfunction as the case may be, in violation of subsequent subsection hereof. 
(1)  Up to three such false alarms per system may occur in a calendar year without the imposition of a penalty. 
(2)  After the second false alarm, a registered written warning shall be sent to the residence. 
(3)  After the third such false alarm, a written order shall be issued to the residence requiring the alarm system to be inspected and the department having jurisdiction, notified of corrective action taken. 
(4)  The fourth such false alarm and every subsequent alarm during any calendar year shall result in a fine of $50.00 per alarm. 
(Ord. of 4-24-2002) 
Sec. 12-53. - Intentional false alarm; penalty. 
    No person shall knowingly or intentionally activate any alarm system when no police or fire emergency exists. No person shall knowingly or intentionally test, repair, adjust, alter, perform maintenance on an alarm system, or cause the same to be tested, repaired, adjusted, altered or maintained if such action could result in a false alarm without first notifying the department having jurisdiction of such test, repair, adjustment, alteration or maintenance and receiving approval for same. The dispatch center having jurisdiction shall be notified prior to the start of any such test, repair, adjustment, alteration or maintenance. Prior to placing system in service, the dispatch center having jurisdiction shall be notified immediately upon completion of such test, repair, adjustment, alteration or maintenance. 
    Any person who violates subsequent subsections of this section shall be fined $50.00 and where applicable, may be subject to additional penalties and prosecution under the General Statutes, as amended, for falsely reporting an incident. 
(Ord. of 4-24-2002) 
Sec. 12-54. - Hearings. 
    Any person receiving an order or notice of violation pursuant to the provisions of this article may contest said order or notice at a hearing before the board of selectman. All demands for a hearing must be made in writing and delivered in person or by mail no later than ten days following receipt of the order or notice of violation. Any person requesting a hearing shall be giving written notice of the date, time and place of the hearing. Such hearing shall be held not less than 15 days, nor more than 30 days from the date of the mailing of the notice; provided, the board of selectman shall grant upon good cause shown any reasonable request by any interested party for postponement or continuance. 
    A person wishing to contest an order or notice of violation shall appear at the hearing and shall have the right to present evidence and cross examine witnesses. A designated official of the department having jurisdiction other than the board of selectman may present evidence on behalf of the department. The board of selectman shall conduct the hearing in order and form and with such methods of proof, as they deem fair and appropriate. The rules regarding the admissibility of evidence shall be strictly applied, but all testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation. The board of selectman shall announce their decision at the end of the hearing. 
    No department having jurisdiction shall waive any fine. The board of selectman shall hear all appeals. 
(Ord. of 4-24-2002) 
Sec. 12-55. - Failure to pay fines. 
    If any person fails to pay within 30 days of the receipt of notice any fine or charge imposed under subsequent sections, interest shall accrue at the rate of 1.5 percent per month on all fines and charges outstanding for periods in excess of 30 days. 
(Ord. of 4-24-2002) 
Sec. 12-56. - Liability; invalidity. 
    The installation and maintenance of alarm systems permitted by this article shall be made at no cost to the town. No liability whatsoever is assumed by the town for the failure of such alarm systems or monitoring facilities or for failure to respond to alarms, or for any other act or omission in connection with such alarm systems. Each residence shall be deemed to hold and save harmless the town, its departments, officers, agents, servants and employees from any and all liability in connection with the permit holder's alarm system. 
(Ord. of 4-24-2002) 
Secs. 12-57-12-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BLIGHT AND NUISANCE ORDINANCE 

Sec. 12-71. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to define, prohibit, and abate blights and nuisances and to protect, preserve, and promote public health, safety, and welfare; and to preserve and protect property values. 
(Ord. of 5-16-2012, § 1) 
Sec. 12-72. - Scope of provisions. 
    This article shall apply uniformly to the maintenance of all residential, nonresidential, and undeveloped premises now in existence or hereafter constructed, maintained, or modified but shall exclude agricultural lands as defined in G.S. § 22-3(b), land dedicated as public or semi-public open space or preserved in its natural state through conservation easements, or areas designated as inland wetlands and watercourses. 
(Ord. of 5-16-2012, § 2) 
Sec. 12-73. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article. 
    Blighted premises. Any building, structure, or parcel of land, except exempt property as defined below, in which at least one of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  It is dilapidated as documented by the building official; 
(2)  It is a fire hazard as determined by the fire marshal or as documented by the fire department; 
(3)  It is determined by the building official or the health department reports that the condition of the building, structure, or parcel of land poses a serious or immediate danger to the safety, health, or general welfare of the community; 
(4)  It is not being adequately maintained. The following factors may be considered in determining whether a building, structure or parcel of land is not being adequately maintained: missing or boarded windows or doors; collapsing or missing walls, roof, or floors; seriously damaged or missing siding; a structurally faulty foundation; garbage; trash; debris; abandoned or inoperable vehicles on the premises in violation of G.S. § 14-150a (unless the premises is a junkyard legally licensed by the State of Connecticut); graffiti; and fire damage; or 
(5)  It is a factor creating a substantial interference with the reasonable and lawful use and enjoyment of abutting premises or which blocks or interferes with the use of any public sidewalk and/or private street or right-of-way or any road sign. 
    Debris. Material which is incapable of immediately performing the function for which it was designed, including, but not limited to: abandoned, discarded, or unused objects; junk comprised of machinery equipment or such as vehicles, automobiles, boats and recreational vehicles which are missing parts, not complete in appearance and/orin an obvious state of disrepair; parts of vehicles; furniture, appliances, and tires which are in the public view. 
    Dilapidated. Any building or structure or part thereof that would not qualify for a certificate of use and occupancy or which is deemed an unsafe structure, and any dwelling or unit which is designated as unfit for human habitation as defined in the state basic building code. 
    Exempt property. Any building or structure undergoing legal demolition, construction, remodeling, restoration, repair, or renovation permitted by the town, provided that the blighted condition will be corrected thereby and further provided that the building or structure remains in compliance with required permits as issued by the Town of Portland. 
(Ord. of 5-16-2012, § 3) 
Sec. 12-74. - Nuisance. 
    No person, firm, corporation, or other legal entity shall cause or allow any blighted premises, as defined in the preceding section, to be created or continued on any real property located within the Town of Portland. Any exempt property, as defined in the preceding section, shall not be considered a blighted premises, and therefore, not subject to the provision hereof. 
(Ord. of 5-16-2012, § 4) 
Sec. 12-75. - Minimum standards. 
(a)  The provisions in this ordinance shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other statutes, codes, ordinances, or regulations which prescribe standards other than are provided in this ordinance. 
(b)  In any case where a provision of this article is found to be in conflict with a provision of any zoning, building, fire, safety, or health ordinance, regulation, or other code of the town or state, the provision which establishes the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety, and property values of the people shall prevail. 
(c)  This article shall not affect violations of any other ordinances, codes, or regulations existing prior to the effective date of this Code, and any such violations may be governed and continue to be punishable under the provisions of those ordinances, codes, or regulations in effect at the time the violation was committed. 
(Ord. of 5-16-2012, § 5) 
Sec. 12-76. - Responsibility for compliance. 
    The owner, lessee, or occupant of premises subject to this article, may be jointly and severally obligated to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-16-2012, § 1) 
Sec. 12-77. - Notice of violations. 
(a)  Complaints may be submitted to the building official by members of the public. Such complaints must be in writing and signed on forms provided by the town. 
(b)  Whenever the building official determines that there has been a violation of any provision of this ordinance, except as to abandoned or inoperable vehicles, such official shall give notice of such violation to the person responsible therefore, as hereinafter provided. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Set forth the violations of this article; 
(3)  Specify a final date for the correction of any violation; 
(4)  Be served upon the owner, lessee, or theoccupant as the case may require; provided, such notice shall be deemed to be properly served upon such owner, lessee, or upon such occupant, if a copy thereof is posted in a conspicuous place in or about the dwelling affected by this notice; or if such person is served with such notice by any other method authorized or required under the laws of this state; 
(5)  Contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will effect permanent compliance with the provisions of this article; and 
(6)  State that the penalties and enforcement provisions of this article will become effective on the final date set for the correction of any violation. 
(c)  Whenever the building Official determines that there has been a violation of this article pertaining to an abandoned or inoperable vehicle(s), the building official shall give notice of such violation to the owner of the property on which such vehicle so remains in compliance with subsection (b), except that: 
(1)  The notice shall specify that said owner has 30 days to correct the violation by removing the vehicle; and 
(2)  Notice of the alleged violation shall be published in a newspaper having substantial circulation in the Town of Portland. 
(d)  Any person notified in accordance with this section who fails to correct any violation by the date specified in said notice shall be in violation of this article and subject to its penalties and enforcement procedures. Any person in violation of this article pertaining to abandoned or inoperable, vehicle(s) shall be subject to the removal and disposition of suevehicle(s) 30 days after notice of the alleged violation in accordance with subsection (c) above. 
(e)  In the absence of the building official the first selectman shall designate a qualified replacement to perform the duties of the building official under this article. 
(Ord. of 5-16-2012, § 7) 
Sec. 12-78. - Penalties and enforcement. 
(a)  Penalties. 
(1)  Each violation of this ordinance shall be considered a separate municipal offense. 
(2)  Each day any violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(3)  Each separate offense under this ordinance may be punishable by a fine of $100.00 payable to the Town of Portland. 
(b)  Enforcement. 
(1)  Any police officer in the Town of Portland is authorized to issue a citation or summons for a violation of this article. If a citation is issued, further proceedings shall be in accord with the provisions of the town's Citation Hearing Procedure Ordinance, as may be revised from time to time. 
(2)  In addition thereto, the first selectman or the board of selectmen is authorized to initiate legal proceedings in the superior court for the immediate correction of the violation(s), collection of any penalties, and the recovery of all costs including costs of remedial action(s) authorized by the court and reasonable attorneys' fees incurred by the Town of Portland to enforce this article. 
(3)  Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, special consideration may be given to individuals who are disabled and who demonstrate both that the violation results from an inability to maintain an owner-occupied residence and that no person with that ability resides therein. Such special consideration shall be limited to the reduction or elimination of fines and/or an agreement that the town or its agents may perform the necessary work and place a lien against the premises for the cost thereof in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
    All fines, court costs, costs of remedial action, and attorneys' fees, as ordered by the court, shall constitute a lien on the subject premises, as provided by G.S. § 7-148aa. 
(Ord. of 5-16-2012, § 8) 
Chapter 13 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]

Sec. 13-1. - Regulation of motor boats on Great Hill Lake. 
    The size of all outboard motors used on Great Hill Lake shall be not more than six horsepower. The speed of all outboard motor boats on Great Hill Lake shall not exceed 12 miles per hour. Any violator of this section, for each violation, may be subject to a fine in accordance with section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 6-28-1955; Ord. of 1-4-1962)

    The use of motors of any kind on Jobs' Pond is prohibited. Any violation of this section may be subject to a fine in accordance with section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 10-3-1960; Ord. of 1-4-1962) 
Sec. 13-3. - Use of parks, recreation areas after dark. 
(a)  No person shall enter upon or engage in any activity in any public park or public outdoor recreation area of the town, including but not limited to tennis courts, softball fields and recreational facilities located on public school grounds, between the hours of sunset and sunrise unless such activity shall be authorized by the parks and recreation commission. 
(b)  The parks and recreation authority is authorized to promulgate and adopt such regulations as it deems necessary to accomplish the purposes of this section. 
(c)  Violation of this section and/or any regulation shall be punishable by a fine in accordance with section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 6-28-1978(2))

Applications that do not fit within the other categories

plus $1.50 per linear foot of new roadway and/or $1.00 per linear foot of common driveway. No "per lot fee" for a proposed lot with an existing dwelling 
Modification to existing approval: ..... $100.00 
Extension of existing approval: ..... $25.00 
Inspection fees: 
Multi-dwelling development: A sum, to be computed by the town engineer, equal to three percent of the estimated cost of infrastructure and site plan improvements as required by the commission, shall be paid at the same time that the bond for E and S controls is submitted. The term "infrastructure and site plan improvements," for the purposes of this section, includes, but is not limited to, the construction of new roads, improvements to existing roads, storm drainage facilities, water and sewer lines, planting of trees or other landscaping, the installation of retaining walls or other structures and erosion and sedimentation controls. 
Subdivision/resubdivision: A sum, to be computed by the town engineer, equal to three percent of the estimated cost of public improvements required by the commission, shall be paid prior to the endorsement of the final record map. The term "public improvements," for the purposes of this section, includes, but is not limited to, the construction of new roads, improvements to existing roads, storm drainage facilities, water and sewer lines, planting of trees or other landscaping, the installation of retaining walls or other structures and erosion and sedimentation controls. 
Preliminary development plan workshop for a mixed use development ..... $500.00 
Special permit for mixed used developments: 
a.  Base fee for processing and administrative handling of application: $20.00 for each 1,000 square feet of commercial establishment and $20.00 for each residential unit. 
b.  Engineering review surcharge: 150 percent of town's written estimate of cost. 
c.  Architectural review surcharge: 150 percent of town's written estimate of cost. 
d.  Additional technical assistance surcharge: 150 percent of town's written estimate of cost. 
e.  Post-approval engineering and inspection fees: 150 percent of town's written estimate of cost. 
The surcharge references in subsections (a)(3)b, c and d of this section shall be paid by the applicant at the time of the submission of the final development plan. Upon final action on the application by the commission, the town shall refund to the applicant any such surcharge funds that exceed the town's actual costs incurred for engineering review, architectural review, or other technical assistance. 
The surcharge referenced in subsection (a)(3)e of this section shall be paid by the applicant prior to endorsement of the approved final development plan. Upon issuance of the final certificate of occupancy associated with the mixed use development, the town shall refund to applicant any such surcharge funds that exceed the town's actual costs incurred for post-approval engineering and inspection fees. 
Note: A sum to be computed by the town engineer equal to three percent of the estimated cost of public improvements required by the commission shall be paid prior to the endorsement of the final record map, except that for mixed use developments, the applicant shall instead pay post-approval engineering and inspections fees as delineated above. 
(4)  For an application for a zoning permit: 
Miscellaneous: ..... $10.00 
Residential new, single-family dwelling: ..... $15.00 
(plus $5.00 for each additional unit up to four families) 
Commercial/nonresidential: 
Less than 5,000 square feet. ..... $30.00 
5,000 to 9,999 square feet. ..... $35.00 
10,000 to 19,999 square feet. ..... $50.00 
20,000 square feet or greater. ..... $75.00 
(Plus the applicable state fee for land use applications) 
(b)  Public improvements. For the purposes of this section, the term "public improvements" includes but is not limited to the construction of new roads, improvements to existing roads, storm drainage facilities, water and sewer lines, planting of trees or other landscaping, the installation of retaining walls or other structures and erosion and sediment controls. 
(c)  Exemption. Boards, commissions, councils and departments of the town are exempt from all fee requirements under subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  Waiver. The applicant may petition the agency to waive, reduce or allow delayed payment of the fee required by subsection (a) of this section. Such petitions shall be in writing and shall state fully the facts and circumstances the agency should consider in its determination under this section. The agency may waive all or part of the application fee if the agency determines that: 
(1)  The activity applied for would clearly result in a substantial public benefit to the environment or to the public health and safety and the applicant would reasonably be deterred from initiating the activity solely or primarily as a result of the amount of the application fee; or 
(2)  The amount of the application fee is clearly excessive in relation to the cost to the town for reviewing and processing the application. 
(e)  Records. The agency shall state upon its record the basis for all actions under this section. 
(Ord. of 10-14-1987(3); Ord. of 6-12-1991; Ord. of 1-4-2006; Ord. of 6-27-2007(2), § 14-1(a)(3); Ord. of 11-7-2007, § 14-1(a)) 
Sec. 14-2. - Community development action plan. 
(a)  The community development action plan dated March 1971 is hereby approved. 
(b)  The community development action plan shall be used for a guide for future community development decisions of the town. 
(c)  In accordance with G.S. § 8-207, the town shall make every reasonable effort to implement and execute the community development action plan. 
(d)  The town, by preparing and maintaining a community development action plan, shall be eligible for state financial assistance from the commissioner of community affairs, and shall apply for such assistance as needed. 
(e)  The community development action plan shall be submitted to the department of community affairs. 
(f)  The town has fulfilled its responsibility for the provision of local grants-in-aid to the extent necessary and required for the preparation and completion of the community development action plan. 
(Ord. of 5-15-1971) 
Secs. 14-3-14-20. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[3]

    A planning and zoning commission consisting of five members, who shall be legal voters and taxpayers of the town, is hereby created. 
(Ord. of 10-6-1947, § 1)

    The town hereby designates its zoning commission as the planning and zoning commission for the town. 
(Ord. of 10-6-1947, § 4)

    The terms of office of the members of the planning and zoning commission shall be as follows: Five persons shall be appointed by the board of selectmen; two of such persons shall be appointed for a period of two years; two for a period of three years; one for a period of four years; and as their terms expire their successors shall be appointed for a period of three years by the board of selectmen.

Sec. 14-45. - Alternate members. 
(a)  Pursuant to the provisions of G.S. § 8-1b, the board of selectmen shall appoint three alternate members of the planning and zoning commission. The three members first appointed shall serve until December 31, 1973. For terms commencing January 1, 1974, three alternate members shall be appointed for terms of one, two and three years, respectively. Thereafter one alternate member shall be appointed annually for a three-year term of office. 
(b)  If a regular member of the planning and zoning commission is absent or is disqualified, the chairman of the commission shall designate an alternate so to act, choosing alternates in rotation so that they shall act as nearly equal a number of times as possible. If any alternate is not available in accordance with such rotation, such fact shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. 
(Ord. of 7-26-1973)

ARTICLE IV. - REGIONAL PLANNING AGENCY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Regional planning agencies, G.S. § 8-31a. 

Sec. 14-61. - Creation. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of section 1 of Public Act 613 of the 1959 Session of the General Assembly, the town hereby adopts Public Act 613 of the General Statutes and joins in the creation of the regional planning agency for Northern Middlesex County Region as defined by the state development commission under the provisions of the Public Act 448 of the 1959 Session of the General Assembly. 
(Ord. of 3-8-1961, § 1) 
Sec. 14-62. - Local representation. 
    The town, having a population of 7,496 according to the federal census of 1960, shall have two representatives on the regional planning agency. Pursuant to section 2 of Public Act 613 of the 1959 Session of the General Assembly, the planning commission of the town duly constituted, pursuant to the provisions of the General Statutes, is hereby authorized to appoint to the regional planning agency one elector of the town for a term of two years. The board of selectmen is hereby authorized to appoint to the agency one elector of the town for a term of one year. Thereafter, all appointments shall be made by the respective commission and board for a period of two years. Appointees under this section shall continue to serve after expiration of their terms until their successors are appointed and take office. Appointees may be reappointed for successive terms. Terms of office of initial appointees shall commence upon establishment of the regional planning agency. 
(Ord. of 3-8-1961, § 2) 
Sec. 14-63. - Resignation of member. 
    Any representative of the regional planning agency who is absent from three consecutive regular meetings of the regional planning agency and any intervening duly called special meetings thereof, shall be considered to have resigned from the regional planning agency and the vacancy shall be filled by the appointing body until the term expires except that the requirements of this section may be waived where illness or other extenuating circumstances makes it impossible for a representative to meet the attendance requirement of this section. 
(Ord. of 3-8-1961, § 3) 
Secs. 14-64-14-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OPEN SPACE AND RECREATIONAL ACQUISITION FUND 

Sec. 14-71. - Fund established. 
    There is hereby established in the town a special fund, which shall be known as the land acquisition fund. 
(Ord. of 3-10-1999) 
Sec. 14-72. - Annual deposit. 
    On an annual basis, commencing with the fiscal year 1999/2000, there shall be deposited into said land acquisition fund, the sum of no less than $50,000.00, provided said amount does not exceed the amount which would be generated by the imposition of a tax of two mills against all of the property subject to tax in the town as shown on the last completed grand list, hereafter referred to as the "maximum deposit." Should said sum of no less than $50,000.00 exceed the maximum deposit, then the amount of the deposit into the land acquisition fund shall be equal to the maximum deposit. 
(Ord. of 3-10-1999) 
Sec. 14-73. - Fund not to lapse or be deemed abandoned. 
    Such land acquisition fund shall not lapse at the close of any fiscal year and shall not be deemed abandoned for failure to make expenditure from or encumbrance of the said fund. 
(Ord. of 3-10-1999) 
Sec. 14-74. - Remaining balance at time of termination. 
    If the land acquisition fund is terminated for any reason, including the revocation of this article, any balance remaining in the fund at the time of such termination shall be transferred to the capital nonrecurring expense fund and shall be used exclusively for the purchase of open space and recreational land as hereafter identified. 
(Ord. of 3-10-1999) 
Sec. 14-75. - Types of land to be considered for acquisition. 
    The following types of land, or interests therein, shall be considered by the board of selectmen for acquisition: 
(1)  Lands which are deemed valuable as "vistas" as defined in the town plan of conservation and development, or revisions thereto. 
(2)  Lands which constitute "wildlife corridors" and "streambelts" as defined in the town plan of conservation and development, or revisions thereto. 
(3)  Lands listed in the state department of environmental protection's natural diversity database. 
(4)  Lands near or contiguous to areas suitable for water-oriented recreation, including the Connecticut River and lakes and ponds. 
(5)  Lands suitable for active recreation, including, but not limited to, activities such as bicycling, skating, ballfields, playing fields, playgrounds and exercise tracks. 
(6)  Lands suitable for urban outdoor public space or rural outdoor public space, as defined in the town plan of conservation and development, or revisions thereto. 
(7)  Lands contiguous to existing town, state or privately owned open space. 
(8)  Lands suitable for passive recreation, including, but not limited to, activities such as hiking, walking, nature-watching, and cross-country skiing. 
(9)  Lands having wetlands with high functional value together with significant geologic, topographic, conservation, historical, and/or archaeological value. 
(Ord. of 3-10-1999) 
Sec. 14-76. - Consideration of acquisition of land. 
    In considering the acquisition of a particular parcel of land, or interest therein, the board of selectmen may obtain written recommendations from any official or board or commission it deems appropriate, and shall follow the provisions of G.S. § 8-24 to refer the matter to the planning and zoning commission for a report. 
(Ord. of 3-10-1999) 
Sec. 14-77. - Purchases in excess of $10,000.00. 
    Real estate purchases in excess of $10,000.00 (or such amount as is specified in the town Charter) shall be approved by action of the special town meeting. 
(Ord. of 3-10-1999) 
Secs. 14-78-14-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - AQUIFER PROTECTION AREA LAND USE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 14-90. - Authority. 
(a)  G.S. § 22a-354o provides that each municipality in which an aquifer protection area is located shall authorize by ordinance an existing board or commission to act as an aquifer protection agency; and 
(b)  It has been determined that it is in the best interest of the town to designate the planning and zoning commission as the town's aquifer protection agency; 
(c)  Be it resolved that the board of selectmen hereby adopts the ordinance from which this article is derived for a municipal aquifer protection agency to register existing regulated activities, to consider permits for new regulated activities, and to inspect regulated facilities. 
(Ord. of 6-1-2005, § 14.90) 
Sec. 14-91. - Designation and membership. 
(a)  In accordance with the provisions of G.S. § 22a-354a et seq., the planning and zoning commission is hereby designated as the aquifer protection agency, hereinafter the "agency," of the town. The staff of the planning and zoning commission shall serve as the staff of the agency. 
(b)  Members of the planning and zoning commission shall serve coexisting terms on the agency. The membership requirements of the agency shall be the same as those of the planning and zoning commission, including, but not limited to, the number of members, terms, method of selection and removal of members, and filling of vacancies. 
(c)  At least one member of the agency or staff of the agency shall complete the course in technical training formulated by the state commissioner of environmental protection, pursuant to G.S. § 22a-354v. 
(Ord. of 6-1-2005, § 14.91) 
Sec. 14-92. - Regulations to be adopted. 
    The agency shall adopt regulations in accordance with G.S. § 22a-354p and RCSA § 22a-354i-3. Said regulations shall provide for: 
(1)  The manner in which boundaries of aquifer protection areas shall be established and amended or changed. 
(2)  The form for an application to conduct regulated activities within the area. 
(3)  Procedures for the regulation of activity within the area. 
(4)  Notice and publication requirements. 
(5)  Criteria and procedures for the review of applications. 
(6)  Administration and enforcement. 
(Ord. of 6-1-2005, § 14.92) 
Sec. 14-93. - Inventory of land use. 
(a)  In order to carry out the purposes of the aquifer program, the agency will conduct an inventory of land use within the area to assess potential contamination sources. 
(b)  The agency will, as soon as practical, inventory land uses overlying the mapped zone of contribution and recharge areas of such aquifers in accordance with guidelines established by the commissioner of the state department of environmental protection pursuant to G.S. § 22a-354f. Such inventory shall be completed not more than one year from the adoption date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Ord. of 6-1-2005, § 14.93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. § 22a-354e.

Chapter 16 - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 9; planning, ch. 14; zoning, app. A; scavengers, § 11-21 et seq.; removal of excess material from excavations, § 17-72. 
State Law reference- Solid waste management, G.S. § 22a-207 et seq.; municipal solid waste management plan, G.S. § 22a-227. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Fees for use for recycling/transfer facility. 
(a)  Fees for the use of the town recycling/transfer facility are as follows: 
(1)  The resident utilizing the recycling/transfer facility for disposal of municipal solid waste may do so only by the use of approved bags. 
(2)  a.  Bags for disposal of municipal solid waste must be pre-purchased from the town at a cost determined by the board of selectmen. 
No municipal solid waste material will be accepted at the recycling facility except material in an approved bag. 
b.  The approved municipal solid waste bags may be purchased at the town hall during normal business hours, 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday. Bags may also be purchased at the recycling/transfer facility and at designated retail outlets approved by the town. 
(3)  Bulky waste: Bulky waste as defined in other sections of this chapter that is brought into the recycling/transfer facility will be disposed of in the appropriate bulky waste container. The material will be weighed at the scale to determine the exact weight. Bulky waste will be charged at a per ton rate as determined by the board of selectmen. 
(4)  The price for tires at the recycling/transfer facility will be determined by the board of selectmen. Permit fees will be established by the board of selectmen. 
(5)  Outside municipal solid waste will be charged at a per ton rate as determined by the board of selectmen. Permit fees will be established by the board of selectmen. 
(Ord. of 5-25-1988(3); Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 12-22-1993; Ord. of 3-2-1994; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-2. - Disposal of appliances containing chlorofluorocarbons. 
(a)  Effective November 23, 1992, any appliance being deposited in the town recycling/transfer facility containing chlorofluorocarbons which require removal will require a permit and a fee as determined by the board of selectmen, per unit deposited. Types of appliances include refrigerators, freezers, air conditioners, humidifiers, and dehumidifiers or generally any appliance containing refrigeration units. 
(b)  Any appliance which has had the chlorofluorocarbons removed must be accompanied by certification by a registered firm. Any appliance which is certified to have had the chlorofluorocarbons removed will not require permit or fee. 
(Ord. of 11-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Editor's note- Provisions enacted by an ordinance adopted Nov. 18, 1992, have been included herein at the discretion of the editor as § 16-2. 
Secs. 16-3-16-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 16-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board of selectmen means the board of selectmen of the Town of Portland, Connecticut. When used in reference to the voting body, "board of selectmen" shall be taken to include the phrase "or a majority thereof." 
    Bulky waste means the definition of the term used in the regulations of the state department of environmental protection, as the same may be amended from time to time. 
    Cardboard means corrugated boxes and similar corrugated and craft paper materials which have a minimum of contamination by food or other material. 
    Commercial hauler or collector means any person who holds himself out for hire to collect solid waste from residential, business, commercial or other establishments. 
    Construction and demolition waste means waste generated during the construction/demolition of any building. 
    Department of public works means the department of public works of the town. 
    Director means the director of public works. 
    Dry-cell battery means any device used for generating electric current through a chemical reaction, including but not limited to nickel-cadmium batteries, carbon batteries, and alkaline batteries. 
    Dwelling means a building containing one or more dwelling units. 
    Garbage means animal, vegetable, or other organic wastes resulting from handling, preparation, cooking, serving, or consumption of food. 
    Glass food container means any glass bottle or jar of any size or shape used to package food or beverage products suitable for human or animal consumption. 
    Leaves means the foliage of trees, bushes, and other plants with a minimum of contamination by rocks, sticks or branches, and pesticides. 
    Magazines means catalogues, magazines, or other similar printed matter. 
    Metal food container means any aluminum, bimetal, steel, tinplated steel, or other metallic can, plate or tray of any size or shape used to package food or beverage products suitable for human or animal consumption. Clean aluminum foil is also included in this category. 
    Mixed paper means junk mail, magazines, file folders, gray cardboard. 
    Municipal solid waste or MSW means that portion of the solid waste stream suitable for disposal, as determined by the department of environmental protection of the state, on the MSW side of the town landfill. 
    Office paper means any used or discarded high-grade white paper and Manila paper including but not limited to paper utilized for writing, typing printing, computer printing and photo copying, which is suitable for recycling and which has a minimum of contamination. 
    Person means anyone who resides in or anyone who owns property in the town, a business, institution, organization, or an approved municipality. 
    P.E.T. plastic food container means any polyethylene terephthalate container of any size of shape used to package beverages. 
    Recyclables means any items designated by this article or by the state department of environmental protection to be separated or diverted as defined below under "recycle." 
    Recycle means to separate or divert an item or items from the solid waste stream for the purposes of processing it, causing it to be processed, or storing it for later processing into a material product, including the production of compost, in order to provide for disposition of the item or items in a manner, other than incineration or landfilling, which will best protect the environment. 
    Recycling container means any container designated as a recycling container by the town recycling committee of the department of public works. 
    Recycling/transfer facility means the town's permitted facility located on Sand Hill Road, for recycling and transfer of recyclables, construction and demolition and municipal solid waste. 
    Refuse means garbage and rubbish. 
    Rubbish means that portion of municipal solid waste that is not garbage. 
    Scrap metal means used or discarded items which consist predominantly of ferrous metals, aluminum, brass, copper, lead, chromium, tin, nickel or alloys thereof, including but not limited to white goods. 
    Scrap tires means discarded rubber or synthetic rubber tires used by or manufactured for vehicles including, but not limited to automobiles, trucks, buses, and trailers. 
    Solid waste means unwanted or discarded materials, including solid, liquid, semi-solid or contained gaseous material. This is an all encompassing term including but not limited to garbage, rubbish, recyclables, bulky waste, and other separately identified waste streams. 
    Solid waste disposal area means the location utilized for ultimate disposal of wastes. 
    Storage battery means batteries used in motor vehicles, airplanes, boats, recreational vehicles, tractors, and like applications, or other lead acid batteries. 
    Transfer facility means the town's solid waste transfer facility. 
    Used waste oil means crankcase oil that has been utilized in internal combustion engines. 
    Yard waste and leaves means brush and the boughs and foliage of trees. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 3; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 16-22-16-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance of March 2, 1994, deleted former §§ 16-22-16-24, relative to solid waste disposal permit class requirements, which derived from §§ 4 and 5 of an ordinance adopted Dec. 20, 1990; an ordinance enacted March 18, 1992; and an ordinance enacted Dec. 22, 1993. 
Sec. 16-25. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance of March 15, 1999, amended the Code by repealing former section 16-25 in its entirety. Former § 16-25 pertained to Class 5 permits; and derived from an ordinance of June 7, 1995. 
Sec. 16-26. - Maintaining current information required. 
    Each permit holder shall give immediate written notice to the town for each change in vehicle or removable bodies used to transport solid waste and of each change in personnel. The permit holder shall be responsible for the operation of any vehicle in the solid waste transfer facility included on his list submitted to the town until such time as the town is given written notice that such vehicle is no longer used by him for that purpose. No vehicle, removable body or operator of any permit holder not listed on the original list or any subsequent written notice filed with the town will be allowed into a solid waste transfer facility. 
(Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Editor's note- Former § 16-26, relative to maintaining current information, was deleted by an ordinance enacted March 2, 1994, and formerly derived from ordinances of 12-20-1990; 3-18-1992; and 12-22-1993. An ordinance of June 7, 1995, reenacted § 16-26 to read as herein set out. 
Secs. 16-27, 16-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Dec. 22, 1993, deleted former §§ 16-27 and 16-28, relative to disposal of solid waste and waste from different towns, which derived from an ordinance enacted Dec. 20, 1990, §§ 6, 7; and ordinance enacted March 18, 1992. 
Sec. 16-29. - Town officials and employees shall refuse to permit deposit of waste in violation of this article. 
(a)  Officials and employees of the town shall refuse to allow any user to dispose of municipal solid waste in the designated rolloff container within the recycling portion of the recycling/transfer facility unless it is in town-approved bags. 
(b)  Any person who knowingly disposes of solid waste containing items designated as recyclables shall be required to remove the load deposited and separate the recyclables according to the state statutes in effect. Repeat offenders will not be permitted to use the recycling/transfer facility for a period of 30 days. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 8; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 3-2-1994; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-30. - Written certification of source and class of solid waste. 
(a)  The first selectman or designated representative, prior to allowing disposal, may require that each permittee, its agent or employee, certify in writing, under penalties of false statement as provided in state statutes, as to the source and class of each load of solid waste brought to the town recycling/transfer facility. 
(b)  If any permit holder, its agent or employee, fails or refuses upon request by the first selectman, or his designated representative, to provide the certification in writing specified in subsection (a) as to any load of waste, the permit holder, its agent or employee shall not be permitted to dispose of the solid waste on the vehicle in the recycling/transfer facility and shall be ordered to remove the vehicle from the area immediately. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 9; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-31. - Permit holders to obey rules of recycling/transfer facility area. 
    All permit holders shall obey all the orders and directions of employees of the town or in charge of town maintained recycling/transfer facility. Permit holders shall dispose of their collections at the points designated by such employees and shall comply with all regulations or the town for the collection of solid waste and disposal thereof in the town recycling/transfer facility. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 10; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-32. - Permit holders to comply with all applicable laws. 
    All permit holders shall comply with all state, federal, and local laws, including but not limited to every section of this article, all statutes, regulations, ordinances, bylaws, permits, and orders applicable to the transportation or disposal of solid waste. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 11; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-33. - Board of selectmen to make additional regulations. 
    The board of selectmen may make additional regulations consistent with this article and all other applicable laws to promote the orderly collection of solid waste and recyclables and disposal thereof in the recycling/transfer facility maintained by the town and for the enforcement of this article. Each regulation shall be in writing and shall become effective upon approval of the board of selectmen and the filing of a copy with the town clerk. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 12; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-34. - Revocation suspension; fines; application for reinstatement. 
(a)  If the first selectman or his designated representative finds that any commercial hauler or collector has dumped more than one cubic foot of volume of solid waste at one time in any area not designated for such disposal by the town or who knowingly mixes other solid waste items with items designated for recycling pursuant to this article or G.S. § 22a241b, he shall, for the first violation, suspend the permit for a period of not less than ten days and not more than 30 days and impose a civil penalty of not greater than $1,000.00; and in the event of a second or subsequent violation the first selectman shall revoke the permit and impose a fine of up to $5,000.00. 
(b)  If the first selectman or his designated representative finds that any commercial establishment has violated the requirements of subsection (c) G.S. § 22a-241(g) shall for the first violation, suspend the permit for a period of not less than ten days and not more than 30 days and impose a fine of not more than $100.00; and in the event of a second violation the first selectman shall revoke the permit and be subject to a fine of up to $500.00. Any permit holder having its permit revoked shall not be eligible for a permit for a period of one year from the effective date of the permit revocation. No commercial establishment whose permit has been revoked will be allowed to defeat these regulations by seeking or obtaining a permit under an assumed name or the name of another person, or engage the services of any other person to collect the solid waste previously collected by the permit holder. 
(c)  Any person having a permit revoked may, within ten days of the mailing or delivery of the written notice of revocation, apply in writing to the board of selectmen requesting a hearing within five days of the filing of the application, the board of selectmen shall set a date for a hearing, which date shall be within ten days of the filing of the application. The hearing may be continued from time to time by the board, as the circumstances require. At such hearing, the applicant may present relevant evidence in support of any claim that he has not violated these regulations and the evidence on which the revocation was based shall be presented. If the board, based on evidence presented, decides that the applicant did not violate this article, it shall reinstate the applicant's permit. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 13; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 3-2-1994; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-35. - Disposal by persons, businesses and organizations. 
(a)  Any person may dispose of solid waste or recyclables generated at his residence in a solid waste disposal area or a recycling center maintained by the town. Any business, institution, social or other organization having a place of business in the town, or an approved municipality, may dispose of solid waste or recyclables generated at such place of business at the recycling/transfer facility maintained by the town.
