No person or business, institution or organization having a place of business in the town, or an approved municipality, shall, directly or indirectly, dispose of solid waste or recyclables generated outside of the town, or said approved municipality in the recycling/transfer facility maintained by the town. If the first selectman finds that any such person, business, institution or organization has violated any applicable law, including but not limited to any section of these regulations, he shall, for the first violation, suspend the right to dispose of materials at the recycling/transfer facility for a period of not less than ten days nor more than 30 days and impose a fine in accordance with the applicable section of this article; and in the event of a second violation within a one-year period, the first selectman may suspend the right for one year and impose a fine in accordance with the applicable section of this article. 
(b)  Any person having its right suspended shall not be eligible to dispose of waste at the recycling/transfer facility for a period of one year after the time the right is suspended. No person whose right has been suspended will be allowed to defeat the purpose of this article by seeking or obtaining such right under an assumed name or the name of another person. Anyone having such right suspended shall apply for the reinstatement as provided in section 16-34(c). 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 14; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-35a. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance of March 15, 1999, amended the Code by repealing former § 16-35a in its entirety. Former § 16-35a pertained to disposal by outside haulers, and derived from an ordinance of June 7, 1995. 
Sec. 16-36. - Permit stickers. 
    Permit stickers shall be required for the use of the recycling/transfer facility by town residents, businesses, institutions, and organizations and approved municipalities. 
(Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-37. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 16-37, relative to filing by current permittees, was deleted by an ordinance enacted March 2, 1994, and formerly derived from § 15 of an ordinance enacted Dec. 20, 1990, and an ordinance enacted March 18, 1992. 
Sec. 16-38. - Recycling required. 
(a)  On and after January 1, 1991, any person who generates solid waste from residential property shall, in accordance with G.S. § 22a-220(c), as amended by section 2 of Public Act 90-220, separate from other solid waste in the items designated for recycling. 
(b)  On and after January 1, 1991, every other person who generates solid waste shall, in accordance with G.S. § 22a-220(c), as amended by section 2 of Public Act 90-220, make provision for the separation from other solid waste of the items designated for recycling pursuant to section 1 subsection (a) of Public Act 90-220. 
(c)  In accordance with state statutes the owner or occupant of each residence or residential dwelling unit shall keep the state mandated recyclable items separate from municipal solid waste when depositing such material at the recycling/transfer facility. 
(d)  The owner or occupant of each place of business, industry, institution, school, office, park, restaurant, public building, or other nonresidential dwelling or building, shall keep the state mandated recyclable items separate from municipal solid waste when depositing such material at the recycling/transfer facility. 
(e)  For the purpose of this section and the collection of municipal solid waste and recyclable materials, every person shall be responsible for separating those recyclable materials designated in subsections (c) and (d) of this section from other garbage and rubbish and prepare said recyclables in the following manner: 
(1)  Newspaper must be clean and may be deposited loose or tied with twine or string. Use of plastic or paper bags to bundle newspaper is unacceptable. 
(2)  Magazines and mixed paper must be clean. Use of plastic bags to bundle magazines and mixed paper is unacceptable. 
(3)  Glass food containers must be rinsed. Glass must not be broken. Glass food containers must be separate from other recyclable materials. The following items shall not be mixed with the glass containers: plastic containers, window glass, mirrors, ceramics, and light bulbs. 
(4)  Metal food containers must be rinsed. Metal food containers must be separate from other recyclable materials. The following items shall not be mixed with the metal food containers: plastic containers, scrap metals, coat hangers, aerosol cans, and paint cans. 
(5)  Corrugated cardboard must be flattened and free of contaminants. 
(6)  Leaves may be deposited in the leaf pile but emptied from any plastic bags. 
(7)  Waste oil must be free of contaminants, including but not limited to antifreeze, gasoline, and solvents. 
(f)  The first selectman, acting through the director of public works, shall enact rules and regulations in conformity with this article. Such rules and regulations shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation within the town and shall be posted in the town clerk's office. 
(g)  Reserved. 
(h)  Each load of solid waste delivered to the town recycling/transfer facility by any person will be subject to an inspection by duly authorized representatives of the department of public works prior to granting permission to dispose of its load at the town recycling/transfer facility. Loads which contain recycled material(s), as defined in subsection (c) of this section, will not be permitted to be dumped in the town recycling/transfer facility unless and until the recyclable materials have been separated and removed from the solid waste. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 17; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-39. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance of March 15, 1999, amended the Code by repealing former § 16-39 in its entirety. Former § 16-39 pertained to responsibilities of collectors, and derived from ordinances of December 20, 1990; March 18, 1992; February 22, 1995; and June 7, 1995. 
Sec. 16-40. - Designation of enforcement agent. 
    The director of public works shall receive notices of violation from collectors issued under section 16-39 and solid waste facilities pursuant to section 2(f) of Public Act 90-220, and be responsible for the enforcement and fines in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 19; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-41. - Scavenging prohibited. 
    There shall be no scavenging allowed at the recycling/transfer facility. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 20; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995, Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Sec. 16-42. - Enforcement and penalties. 
    Any person or entity violating any provision of this article or any rules or regulations promulgated hereunder shall be fined in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. of 12-20-1990, § 14; Ord. of 3-18-1992; Ord. of 2-22-1995; Ord. of 6-7-1995; Ord. of 3-15-1999) 
Chapter 17 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; planning, ch. 14; traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 19; utilities, ch. 20; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Power of town to control the excavation of the highways and streets, G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(C)(iii); to lay out, construct, etc., streets, sidewalks, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(C)(i); to provide for lighting the streets, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(4)(F); to provide for the planting, etc., of shade and ornamental trees on the streets and public grounds, G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(A)(v); to keep open, etc., the streets, sidewalks, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(C)(ii); to require owners or occupants of land adjacent to any sidewalk to remove snow, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(C)(v); to regulate and prohibit the excavation, etc., of sidewalks, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(C)(iv); to prohibit and regulate the discharge of drains from roofs of buildings over or upon the sidewalks, streets, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(B)(iv); to keep the streets, sidewalks and public places free from undue noises and nuisances, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(F)(i); highways and bridges, G.S. § 13a-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Curb lines. 
    The town shall establish curb lines, and the board of selectmen shall designate the location of such curb lines. 
(Ord. of 5-9-1934) 
Secs. 17-2-17-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TOWN STREETS AND HIGHWAYS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contractor means any person doing business subject to this article, either as principal contractor or as subcontractor. 
    Pavement means all surfaces installed and designated to dispose of surface water and to carry or guide vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
    Street or highway means the entire width of any dedicated or otherwise legally acquired public highway under the jurisdiction of the town. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 6) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-22. - Discharge of water prohibited. 
    No person shall lay, construct, open or maintain any drain or conductor pipe in such manner that the water from the same is discharged upon any sidewalk, any town highway, or public ground in the town. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 2) 
Sec. 17-23. - Stop work order. 
(a)  Whenever a permit has been issued under this article and the regulations herein are not complied with, a stop work order shall be delivered to the person holding such permit, or his representative. Upon such delivery, all work shall cease, the excavation refilled or otherwise made safe and secure, and the permit shall be deemed to be suspended until the director of public works authorizes in writing a resumption of the work. The director of public works or his authorized agent shall be authorized to issue stop work orders. 
(b)  Any work not satisfactorily completed under this article may be completed by the town and all costs for such work shall be billed to the person taking out such permit. No further permits shall be issued to such person so billed until the balance owed the town is paid. All remittances shall be payable to the town treasurer. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 11) 
Sec. 17-24. - Notice of work to be done. 
    Call Before You Dig (C.B.Y.D.) must be notified at least two full working days prior to any work under the provisions of this article is commenced, and no permit will be issued without an appropriate C.B.Y.D. ticket number. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 4) 
Sec. 17-25. - Exemptions. 
    All municipal departments, authorities, commissions, municipal utilities, or agencies shall be exempt from this article, providing that the same shall make excavations using their own work force and equipment. No permit fee shall be required of a private contractor or contractors doing work for the town or any department, agency or commission thereof when done under the supervision of the director of public works. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 5) 
Sec. 17-26. - Violations. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not more than $50.00 per day for each provision of the article thus violated. Each day of such violation shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 10) 
Secs. 17-27-17-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 17-46. - Permit required. 
    No person shall build, maintain, construct, reconstruct, relocate, or otherwise use a driveway or entrance or exit to a town highway or street from private land without first obtaining a written permit from the director of public works or his duly authorized representative. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 3) 
Sec. 17-47. - Specifications. 
    The board of selectmen shall adopt, and may amend as required, specifications concerning construction of driveways abutting town highways. In adopting or amending specifications, the board of selectmen shall include, in their consideration, the location of the driveway with respect to its effect on highway drainage, highway safety, the width and character of the highway affected, the density of traffic thereon and the character of such traffic. No permit shall be issued unless the driveway entrance or exit shall conform to the specifications. Such specifications shall include the requirement for a bond to ensure completion of all required improvements. Should any driveway improvements not be completed as required within the time limits as set forth in the specifications, then the bond shall be called and the work completed by the town as required by the specifications. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 4) 
Sec. 17-48. - Variances from specifications concerning construction of driveways. 
    A property owner may request a variance from the specifications adopted by the board of selectmen concerning construction of driveway abutting town highways. Said request for a variance must be submitted in writing to the first selectman and shall set forth the location of the property and the specific section(s) of the specifications sought to be varied. Said request for a variance shall further set forth the reason(s) for which the variance is requested, as well as all reasonable options and alternatives to the variance which the applicant has analyzed and reviewed prior to making the request. Upon receipt of said variance application, the first selectman shall schedule the variance request for determination by the board of selectmen. The applicant shall be notified in writing of the date on which his request will be considered by the board of selectmen. It shall be entirely within the discretion of the board of selectmen whether to allow the applicant or others to make a presentation prior to its decision upon said request for a variance. The board of selectmen may grant the request for a variance only where, owing to conditions especially affecting the subject site, but not affecting generally the district in which the site is located, a literal enforcement of the driveway specifications would result in exceptional difficulty or unusual hardship so that substantial justice will be done and the public safety and welfare will be secured by the granting of the request for a variance. The board of selectmen shall not be required to decide upon any request for a variance involving the same property for a period of one year after its decision upon said earlier request. 
(Ord. of 11-12-1997) 
Secs. 17-49-17-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 17-66. - Permit required. 
    No person shall make any excavation, ditch, digging or otherwise alter, open or remove the surface of any street or highway in the town until a permit has been obtained from the director of public works or his authorized agent. Application for a permit shall be made on forms provided by the director of public works and shall be accompanied by a sketch or drawing describing the work to be done. The sketch or drawing shall be in sufficient detail to facilitate an inspection of the excavation by town personnel. The department of public works may require detailed plans and specifications and other engineering data to be submitted with the application when he shall deem such to be necessary. The permit shall be obtained at least 72 hours prior to commencement of excavation activities. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 1) 
Sec. 17-67. - Fees. 
    Contractors applying for a permit issued pursuant to this division shall pay a fee to the town in the amounts computed by measuring the surface area of such excavation as follows: 
(1)  $10.00 for the first 500 square feet of excavation or fraction thereof; and 
(2)  $10.00 for each additional 500 square feet of excavation or fraction thereof, as indicated below: 
Surface Area Permit Fee Up to 500 s.f. $10.00 501 s.f. to 1,000 s.f. $20.00 1,001 s.f. to 1,500 s.f. $30.00 1,501 s.f. to 2,000 s.f. $40.00 2,001 s.f. to 2,500 s.f. $50.00 2,501 s.f. to 3,000 s.f. $60.00 3,001 s.f. to 3,500 s.f. $70.00 3,501 s.f. to 4,000 s.f. $80.00 4,001 s.f. to 4,500 s.f. $90.00 5,001 s.f. to 5,000 s.f. $100.00 (Continuing in $10.00 increments for each 500 s.f. or fraction thereof.)  
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 8) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, ch. 11. 
Sec. 17-68. - Insurance and bond. 
(a)  No permit for an excavation in any town street or highway in the town shall be granted until the contractor shall file with the first selectman proof of insurance as follows: 
(1)  Automobile. $1,000,000.00 combined single limit for bodily injury and/or property damage. 
(2)  Comprehensive general liability (including products and completed operations). $1,000,000.00 combined single limit for bodily injury and/or property damage. 
(3)  Worker's compensation. Limit per state statute, $100,000.00 employer's liability. 
(4)  Umbrella. $1,000,000.00 per occurrence. 
(b)  Proof of a performance bond in the minimum amount of $5,000.00 and in greater amounts as indicated below. Such performance bond will be an amount relative to the area to be excavated as determined by the director of public works, all predicated on the contractor restoring the street or highway to a condition as approved by the director of public works. 
Surface Area Bond Amount Up to 500 s.f. $5,000.00 501 s.f. to 800 s.f. $5,000.00 801 s.f. to 1,000 s.f. $5,000.00 1,001 s.f. to 1,200 s.f. $6,000.00 1,201 s.f. to 1,400 s.f. $7,000.00 1,401 s.f. to 1,600 s.f. $8,000.00 1,601 s.f. to 1,800 s.f. $9,000.00 1,801 s.f. to 2,000 s.f. $10,000.00 (Continuing to $1,000.00 increments for each 200 s.f. or fraction thereof.)  
(c)  All such bonds and insurance coverages shall be for a term of at least one year and shall be kept in force continuously until the maintenance provisions hereinafter specified are satisfied. Evidence of renewal of coverage shall be furnished annually to the first selectman's office. 
(d)  The contractor shall hold harmless and indemnify the town for any and all liability, damages, and costs which may in any manner be incurred by the town by reason of or in connection with the issuance of a permit for such excavation or by reason of any act or omission of the contractor, his agents, or servants. 
(e)  Contractors and public service corporations may dispense with the filing of a separate insurance policy and bond for each excavation by filing annually with the first selectman's office the proper evidence of insurance coverage and performance bond hereinbefore required, provided however, that an application must be made for a permit for each separate excavation. Evidence of insurance coverage and performance bond shall be filed in the form and in companies or sureties satisfactory to the office of the first selectman. The surety company shall be licensed to do business in this state. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 9) 
Sec. 17-69. - Protection of utilities. 
    The contractor shall at all times take all proper precautions to safeguard any sewer lines, water mains, electrical conduits, telephone conduits, gas mains, gas lines, or appurtenances encountered in excavation, and shall properly maintain such installations so as to provide uninterrupted service of the same. In locations where the use of power equipment will endanger such installations, the work must be done by hand labor. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 12) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 20. 
Sec. 17-70. - Manner of cutting. 
    Excavations must be made in open cut and no tunneling will be allowed except by special written permission from the director of public works. Trenches shall be braced and sheeted when needed to meet applicable federal and state trench safety regulations. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 12) 
Sec. 17-71. - Placement of excavated material on private property. 
    No excavated material is to be placed on private property without written permission from the property owner. Such written permission shall be obtained by the contractor and filed with the director of public works prior to placing excavated material on private property. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 12) 
Sec. 17-72. - Removal of excess material. 
    All excess material removed from any excavation in streets, highways, town properties or rights-of-way granted in favor of the town that is not required or suitable for backfilling the excavation will remain the property of the town and must be removed to and/or disposed of at the site of the town landfill, the entrance to which is located off Sand Hill Road. A landfill permit will be required in accordance with the landfill regulations in force. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 12) 
Cross reference- Solid waste management, ch. 16. 
Sec. 17-73. - Protection of public. 
    All excavations shall be protected at all times by barricades, danger warning signs, and during the night by flares or warning lights. Only one-half of the traveled portion of the street or highway shall be excavated, permitting safe passage of vehicular traffic on the remaining half. Under no circumstances shall an excavation or opening be made across the width of the entire street or highway, or in such a manner as to prohibit the safe passage of vehicular traffic without the written permission of the director of public works and the first selectman. Such written permission shall be obtained in advance of such excavation or opening. The director of public works and the first selectman may prescribe such conditions as they shall deem necessary to permit the safe passage of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 13) 
Sec. 17-74. - Restoration-Backfill. 
(a)  All excavations provided for in this division shall be backfilled with bank-run gravel or material approved by the director of public works. Material removed from the excavations may be used for backfill only with permission of the director of public works or his authorized agent. All backfilling must be done in properly compacted layers not exceeding 12 inches in depth after compaction. No muck, clay, frozen earth, topsoil, stones over six inches in any dimension or other deleterious material shall be placed in the excavation but shall be disposed of as indicated above. The approved backfill material shall be placed and compacted at a moisture content between four and six percent (based on dry density, by weight), or within two percent of the optimum moisture content as determined by the moisture-density relationship test specified in A.S.T.M. D-1557. 
(b)  At locations where the contractor elects to consolidate the backfill material by the so called "Ho-Pac" method, the compacted layers shall not exceed four feet in depth after compaction. The vibratory compactor shall be placed directly on the backfill surface and the compaction effort shall be continued until no further visible settlement occurs. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 14) 
Sec. 17-75. - Same-Pavement. 
(a)  After the excavation has been backfilled and compacted as indicated above, eight inches of processed aggregate base shall be placed and compacted in two four-inch layers. The material used and the method of compaction shall be in conformance with the state department of transportation standard specifications for roads, bridges, and incidental construction, Form 813, and future revisions thereto. A temporary bituminous patch, at least two inches in depth, shall be placed and compacted on top of the aggregate base so that the surface of the patched excavation is slightly domed above the adjacent pavement. After a minimum period of 60 days and a maximum of 360 days, the temporary patch material and any fouled aggregate base, shall be removed and replaced with new aggregate base, if needed, and permanent bituminous material as indicated below: 
(1)  Industrial roads: 11/2 inches of bituminous concrete surface course on 41/2 inches of premixed bituminous concrete base. 
(2)  Other town roads: Two inches of bituminous concrete surface course on two inches of bituminous concrete binder course. 
(b)  Industrial roads are those classified as such in the town's zoning regulations. The bituminous pavement material and method of placement shall also be in conformance with Form 813. After the removal of the temporary patch and prior to the placement of the permanent bituminous material, the existing pavement will be cut back as directed by the director of public works or his authorized representative to create vertical faces which will either be parallel or perpendicular to the new pavement. The vertical faces will be sealed with 85/100 asphaltic material to ensure a good bond between the old and new pavement material. The surface of the repaved excavation shall be flush with the adjacent pavement. Curbs and sidewalks are considered a part of the pavement and are to be restored to their original condition in accordance with applicable town standards and specifications. 
(c)  All grassed or open areas are to be rough graded with boulders larger than six inches removed from the site. All lawned areas are to be fine graded with four inches of topsoil and seeded as approved by the director of public works. 
(d)  All other highway facilities, signs, pavement markings, sewers or subsurface structures shall be restored to their original condition before the excavation was made. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 15) 
Sec. 17-76. - Maintenance. 
(a)  The contractor shall be responsible for the maintenance of the repaired patch during the life of the temporary patch and for a period of one year after the acceptance of the permanent patch by the director of public works. In the event that it is necessary to make repairs to the excavation or restoration of the pavement during the one-year period, such guarantee shall be extended for an additional period of 60 days. The performance bond shall include such conditions of maintenance within its provisions. 
(b)  Any patches not satisfactorily maintained by the contractor may be repaired by the town and the following charges shall be billed to the person responsible for the patch: $150.00 per repair on weekdays and $250.00 per repair on weekends and holidays. No further permits shall be issued to the person so billed until the balance owed the town is paid. All remittances shall be payable to the town treasurer. 
(Ord. of 11-9-1988, § 16) 



Secs. 17-77-17-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-81. - Expenditures. 
    The board of selectmen be and are hereby authorized to build and maintain sidewalks to an extent that will not exceed in cost 15 percent of the amount that is annually expended on its highways. 
(Ord. of 12-18-1934) 
Sec. 17-82. - Construction and repair. 
    Whenever the owner of any land fronting upon any street or highway in this town shall neglect to make, pave or repair any sidewalk within the time and in the manner ordered by the first selectman, or shall neglect or refuse to keep his sidewalk in good repair, it shall be the duty of the first selectman to make or repair the same and the cost of making or of repairs and interest thereon shall be the responsibility of the owner of the adjoining premises. 
(Ord. of 12-18-1934; Ord. of 1-8-1997) 
Sec. 17-83. - Assessments and collection. 
    The board of selectmen shall determine the assessment for the cost of making or of repairs to sidewalks and the tax collector be and is hereby authorized to collect said assessments upon the same conditions as the tax of real property is levied and collected. 
(Ord. of 12-18-1934) 
Secs. 17-84-17-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SNOW AND ICE ON SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Parking during snow and ice removal, § 19-22. 

Sec. 17-96. - Adoption of statutory provisions. 
    The provisions of G.S. § 7-163a are hereby adopted effective November 22, 1987. 
(Ord. of 10-14-1987(5), § a) 
Sec. 17-97. - Liability of town. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of G.S. § 13a-149 or any other General Statute or special act, the town shall not be liable to any person injured in person or property caused by the presence of snow or ice on a public sidewalk unless the town is the owner or person in possession and control of land abutting such sidewalk, other than land used as a highway or street, provided that the town shall be liable for its affirmative acts with respect to such sidewalk. 
(Ord. of 10-14-1987(5), § b) 
Sec. 17-98. - Liability of abutting property owner. 
    The owner or person in possession and control of land abutting a public sidewalk shall have the same duty of care toward the portion of the sidewalk abutting his property as the town had prior to November 22, 1987, and shall be liable to persons injured in person or property where a breach of such duty is the proximate cause of such injury. 
(Ord. of 10-14-1987(5), § c) 
Sec. 17-99. - Limitation on commencement of action. 
    No action to recover damages for injury to the person or to property caused by the presence of snow or ice on a public sidewalk against a person who owns or is in possession and control of land abutting a public sidewalk shall be brought but within two years from the date when the injury is first sustained. 
(Ord. of 10-14-1987(5), § d) 
Sec. 17-100. - Removal by town. 
    If snow or ice shall remain on any public sidewalk, and if the sidewalk shall not be covered or treated with sand or some other suitable substance to protect the public from personal injury and property damage from such snow or ice for more than 12 hours after the owner or person in possession or control of the property abutting such sidewalk and legally liable to clear the same has been notified by the town to clear the same, the public works department may cause the same to be cleared or properly covered or treated and shall collect the expense from such owner or person. Failure of the public works department to cause to clear or cover the sidewalk shall not make the town responsible for any resulting injury or damage. 
(Ord. of 10-14-1987(5); Ord. of 1-8-1997) 
Sec. 17-101. - Removal by owner, tenant or occupant; removal by town upon default of owner, tenant or occupant. 
(a)  The owner, tenant or occupant of premises adjoining and fronting on any sidewalk within the town shall cause to be removed therefrom any and all snow, sleet, and ice within 12 hours after the same shall have fallen, been deposited, or found, or within 12 hours after sunrise, when the same shall have fallen in the night season; and whenever any such sidewalk, or any part thereof, shall be covered with ice, the owner, agent, or occupant of the building or lot adjacent thereto, shall, within the space of 12 hours thereafter, during the daytime, cause such sidewalk to be made safe and convenient by removing the ice therefrom, or by covering the same with sand or some other suitable substance. 
(b)  Violation of any provision of this section shall be deemed an infraction. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. § 51-164m. 
(c)  The first selectman may direct the public works department to remove or have removed any snow or ice therefrom upon the default or neglect of the owner, tenant or occupant of such adjoining premises to comply with such by-laws and the expenses of such removal shall be paid by the owner of the premises adjoining such walk. 
(Ord. of 12-18-1934; Ord. of 1-8-1997) 
Secs. 17-102-17-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NUMBERING BUILDINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6. 

Sec. 17-121. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to promote public safety and convenience through a building numbering system ensuring that addresses can be identified with ease and speed which is essential for the quick response of emergency services, such as fire, police and emergency medical care. 
(Ord. of 8-9-1989, § 1) 
Sec. 17-122. - Owner's duty. 
    It shall be the duty of the owners of all residential, commercial, industrial and other buildings within the town to identify such buildings or parts thereof with numbers as herein provided. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, maintain, or allow to remain on a building or any unit thereof any number other than the one required by this article. 
(Ord. of 8-9-1989, § 2) 
Sec. 17-123. - Assignment of numbers. 
(a)  The town may assign to each building, or part of a building, an identification number by which such building or part thereof shall be designated. The town shall be authorized to change the identification number of any building or part thereof at any time and from time to time, whenever such change is deemed necessary or appropriate. 
(b)  All new buildings on any street or highway within the town shall have affixed thereto identification numbers assigned hereunder prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
(Ord. of 8-9-1989, § 3) 
Sec. 17-124. - Notice of assignment. 
    Whenever the town, acting in accordance with this article, shall have assigned an identification number to a building, they shall send to the owner written notice thereof, and shall direct such owner to affix to such building the number or numbers assigned, to be completed within 30 days after the sending of such notice. 
(Ord. of 8-9-1989, § 4) 
Sec. 17-125. - All buildings to be numbered. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of every building existing in the town on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives, without prior notice, to affix the identification previously assigned to such building, or, in the absence of such assignment, the identification number which customarily has been used for such building. Such numbers shall be affixed within 30 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives. 
(Ord. of 8-9-1989, § 5) 
Sec. 17-126. - Specifications and location of numbers. 
(a)  The identification number of a building shall be located on the exterior front of the building and/or on a post, sign, mailbox or other device located between the building and the public or private street on which it fronts. The numerals shall be at least 31/2 inches in height, shall be of a color contrasting with the color of the background material to which they are affixed and shall be made of substantial and permanent material. Spelled out numbers are not acceptable. The identification number shall be placed or affixed so as not to be easily effaced or removed, and shall be positioned not less than four feet nor more than ten feet from the surface of the ground directly below them. The identification numerals shall be sufficient and so placed as to assure clear visibility and legibility when the building which they identify is viewed from one or more points along the center line of the public or private street on which it fronts. 
(b)  If a building is set back more than 100 feet from the center line of the street on which it fronts, or if the building's identification number cannot be made clearly visible from such street because of an intervening obstruction, the identification number shall also be affixed to a post, sign, mailbox or other device which shall be located within ten feet of the driveway entrance which provides the closest vehicular access to the building or part of the building to which the identification number is assigned. 
(c)  For buildings containing two or more residential, business or commercial units which have entrances from interior passageways, identification numbers shall be affixed on or adjacent to every exterior door of the building as well as on or next to the entrance door of each individual unit. 
(d)  For building complexes consisting of two or more residential, business or commercial units served by separate driveways, signs shall be posted at the entrance to each such driveway, or if two or more of such driveways intersect, at each intersection, listing the identification number of the unit served by each driveway. In addition, identification numbers shall be affixed on or next to every entrance door of each building unit. 
(Ord. of 8-9-1989, § 6) 
Sec. 17-127. - Penalty. 
    Every owner of a building who violates section 17-125 or 17-126, or who refuses or neglects to comply with any other provision of this article, shall be punishable by a fine of $5.00 per day at the end of 30 days after the issuance of written notice. 
(Ord. of 8-9-1989, § 7) 
Chapter 18 - TAXATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Boards of finance, G.S. § 7-340 et seq.; finance and taxation, G.S. § 12-40 et seq.; general provisions, G.S. § 7-398 et seq.; municipal auditing act, G.S. § 7-391 et seq.; municipal bond issues, G.S. § 7-369 et seq.; municipal reserve fund, G.S. § 7-359 et seq.; town deposit fund, G.S. § 7-350; treasurer, G.S. § 7-79 et seq.; uniform fiscal years, G.S. § 7-381 et seq. 

Sec. 18-1. - Elimination of real estate tax lists. 
    The elimination of listing real estate in accordance with the approval of the state tax commissioner as set forth in the state statutes is hereby approved. 
(Ord. of 10-6-1952) 
Sec. 18-2. - Taxes not in excess of $100.00 payable in one payment. 
    The tax collector shall collect all property taxes not in excess of $100.00 due and payable in a single payment in accordance with G.S. § 12-144. 
(Ord. of 5-2-1960; Ord. of 7-11-2001) 
Sec. 18-3. - Exemption for solar heating. 
    A tax exemption in the town for any building or addition to any building equipped with the solar energy heating or cooling system is hereby authorized as provided in G.S. § 12-81(56). 
(Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 18-4. - Properties acquired by tax-exempt organizations. 
(a)  The property tax exemption authorized by any of the subsections (7) through (16) inclusive of section 12-81 of the general statutes shall be effective as of the date of acquisition of the property to which the exemption applies, and the provisions of this article shall apply to all such properties acquired by tax-exempt organizations subsequent to September 30, 1994. 
(b)  Any tax-exempt organization eligible under this section shall file an application with the board of selectmen for the appropriate abatement and reimbursement for any tax paid by it for a period subsequent to the date of acquisition and for any tax paid by the prior owner for a period subsequent to said date for which such organization reimbursed such owner on the transfer of title to such property which reimbursement shall be based on an adjustment on a fiscal year basis. In the event taxes have not been paid for a payment period subsequent to the date of adjustment, such taxes shall be abated upon appropriate application, the board of selectmen shall authorize the appropriate refund or abatement of taxes and shall give notice of such action to the tax collector. 
(c)  Such tax-exempt organization shall place the deed or other instrument by which such property was conveyed on the town records within ten days after such instrument is delivered to it, in which event said organization shall be entitled to the benefits of this section from the date of acquisition of the property. If such tax-exempt organization fails so to record the deed or instrument, it shall be entitled to the benefits of this section only from the date on which such deed or other instrument shall have been recorded on the land records. 
(Ord. of 10-25-1995) 
Sec. 18-5. - Exemption for any ambulance type and retrofitted handicapped vehicle. 
    There is created pursuant to G.S. § 12-81C and P.A. 98-125, an exemption from personal property taxation for any ambulance-type motor vehicle which is exclusively for the purpose of transporting any medically incapacitated individual, or for specially rigged or retrofitted (i.e., changed after its manufacture to accommodate the owner's disability), privately owned vehicles operated by a handicapped individual. Excluded from this section are any vehicles used to transport individuals for payment. Individuals requesting said exemption must show proof to the town assessor that the vehicle was modified for use by a handicapped individual or for the transport of a handicapped individual. 
(Ord. of 9-23-1998) 
Secs. 18-6-18-9. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Aug. 3, 2016, repealed § 18-10, which pertained to tax abatement for volunteer firefighters, and derived from ordinances adopted Sept. 26, 2001; and June 11, 2003. 
Secs. 18-11-18-14. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-15. - Supplementary tax relief. 
(a)  Eligibility for benefits; age, disability and income requirements. 
(1)  Subject to the limitations hereinafter set forth, real property tax deferral benefits shall be available with respect to real property located in the town owned and occupied as their principal residence by residents of the town who are: 
a.  65 years of age and over or whose spouse, living with them, are 65 years of age or over; or 60 years of age or over and the surviving spouse of a taxpayer qualified under this plan at the time of spouse's death; or with respect to real property located in the town occupied as their principal residence on which such residents or spouses are liable for taxes under section 12-48 of the state General Statutes; or 
b.  Under age 65 and eligible in accordance with applicable federal regulations to receive permanent total disability benefits under social security or who have not been engaged in employment covered by social security and accordingly have not qualified for benefits thereunder but have become qualified for permanent total disability benefits under any federal, state or local government retirement or disability plan, including the Railroad Retirement Act and any government-related teachers' retirement plan in which requirements with respect to qualifications for such permanent total disability benefits are comparable to such requirements under social security. 
(2)  All such residents or their spouses shall have been taxpayers of the town for one year immediately preceding their receipt of tax benefits under this plan and their total adjusted gross income for purposes of the federal income tax, plus any other income not included in such adjusted gross income (the total of which shall be called "qualifying income"), shall not exceed $2,000.00 over the state limits of the homeowners' tax relief program. Evidence of such income shall be required and a signed affidavit shall be submitted to the town assessor when application for benefits under this plan is filed. The amount of any Medicaid payments made on behalf of such homeowner or the spouse of such homeowner shall not constitute income. 
(3)  Such person has resided at and paid real estate taxes on a residence located in the town for a period of five consecutive years prior to his application for tax relief and does not owe delinquent taxes to the town. 
(b)  Participation in state programs required. All such residents or spouses who may qualify for tax relief under G.S. §§ 12-129b through 12-129d, inclusive, 12-129n and/or 12-170aa must apply for and be included, if qualified, in such program or programs as a condition precedent to qualifying for and receiving benefits under supplementary tax relief plan (STRP). 
(c)  Limitations on benefits. 
(1)  For those such residents or spouses receiving or eligible to receive benefits under the state tax relief program referred to in subsection (b) above, the benefit available under STRP shall not exceed, in the aggregate, 75 percent of the total amount of the tax which would be laid against the taxpayer for said real property, except for said G.S. §§ 12-129b through 12-129d, inclusive, 12-129n and/or 12-170aa and STRP. Thus, the tax deferment available to such residents or their spouses under STRP shall be equal to the difference between the abatement afforded by such state programs and 75 percent of the taxes laid against the taxpayer for such real property. If benefits received under state programs exceed 75 percent of the total taxes due, no tax deferment benefit shall be available under STRP. 
(2)  For those residents or their spouses who otherwise meet the requirements for such state program or programs but whose incomes are in excess of the state limits, the following schedule of tax deferments will apply if the applicant meets the income requirements specified in subsection (a)(2) above for that year: 
a.  For unmarried homeowners, a tax deferment of 50 percent of the total tax levied against the taxpayer shall be applied. 
b.  For married homeowners, a tax deferment of 60 percent of the total tax levied against the taxpayer shall be applied. 
(3)  There shall be no tax deferment benefits available under STRP where income exceeds said limits specified in subsection (a)(2) above. 
(d)  Fractional interests or multiple-family dwellings. The real property tax deferral relief provided under STRP may, in any case where title to the real property is recorded in the name of the taxpayer or his spouse and any other person or persons, be prorated to reflect the fractional share of such taxpayer or spouse, or, if such real property is a multiple-family dwelling, such relief may be prorated to reflect the fractional portion of such property occupied by the taxpayer. 
(e)  Unit owners of cooperatives. Pursuant to G.S. § 12-129n, subsection (g), the tax relief provided under STRP shall be available to persons who qualify in accordance with the requirements of this section and who are unit owners of a cooperative. The amount of relief shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of G.S. § 12-129n, subsection (g)(2). 
(f)  Interest, lien and repayment. 
(1)  All tax deferments granted under STRP shall bear interest from the date said deferred taxes become due (July 1 and January 1 of each year) until fully paid. The rate of interest payable on such deferred taxes shall be set annually and based on the prime interest rate set by the Federal Reserve Board on June 30 of each fiscal year. 
(2)  As a condition precedent to receiving the tax deferral benefits, an applicant shall execute a tax deferral lien on a form provided by the assessor, in favor of the town at the time application for benefits hereunder is made, to be recorded on the town land records by the town tax collector upon the approval of such application by the town assessor. 
(3)  Upon approval the applicant shall cause his insurer to name the town as an additional insured on any insurance policy covering the subject property. 
(4)  Taxes deferred under STRP shall be due and payable, together with accumulated interest thereon, at such time as the real property in question is sold and conveyed, whether or not for value, or title is transferred or upon the death of such taxpayer (unless a spouse qualified under subsection (a) hereof survives), whichever event first occurs. 
(g)  Annual application required. 
(1)  Any resident believing themselves entitled to tax deferments under STRP for any assessment year, shall complete an application form and submit the form for approval to the town assessor at any time from February 1 to and including May 15 of the year for which the tax deferment benefit is claimed. In completing such application, the applicant shall present to the assessor, in substantiation of his application, a copy of applicant's federal income tax return, including a copy of social security statement of earnings for such applicant and that of applicant's spouse, if filed separately, for such applicant's taxable year ending immediately prior to the submission of such application or, if not required to file a return, such other evidence of qualifying income in respect to such taxable year as may be required by the assessor. 
(2)  When the assessor is satisfied that the applicant is qualified for the tax deferment in accordance with STRP, the assessor shall issue a certificate of tax deferment showing the amount of the taxes deferred to the applicant and deliver a copy of said certificate of deferment, together with the executed tax deferral lien, to the town tax collector. 
(3)  The amount of the tax deferment approved shall be applied to the real property tax payable by the resident taxpayer for the assessment year in which such application is submitted and approved. If any such resident taxpayer has qualified for a tax deferment under STRP, the deferment shall be applied or prorated uniformly over the number of installments in which the real property tax is due. 
(4)  The total of all deferment granted under the provisions of this ordinance for any tax year shall not exceed an amount equal to one-quarter percent of the town's current adopted operating budget in effect as of February 1. In the event it exceeds one-quarter percent of the budget, the tax deferment given to eligible persons shall be prorated uniformly to keep the total amount of town tax deferments within the statutory limit using the following formula: 
FORMULA: 
1/4 of 1% of Total Operating Budget = Prorate % Cost of Program  
Prorate % × 100% Tax Increase For That Fiscal Year = Prorated Tax Deferments 
(Ord. of 9-26-2001; Ord. of 6-11-2003) 
Secs. 18-16-18-19. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-20. - Property tax relief for elderly homeowners. 
(a)  Qualification and requirements. 
(1)  An owner of real property or any tenant for life or for a term of years liable for property taxes under G.S. § 12-48 who meets the qualifications stated in this subsection shall be entitled to pay the tax levied on such property, calculated in accordance with the provisions of subsection (a)(2) of this section for the first year the claim for such tax relief is filed and approved in accordance with the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, and such person shall be entitled to continue to pay the amount of such tax or such lesser amount as may be levied in any year, during such subsequent year that such person meets such qualifications, and the surviving spouse of such owner or tenant, qualified in accordance with the requirement pertaining to a surviving spouse in this subsection, or any owner or tenant possessing a joint interest in such property with such owner at the time of such owner's death and qualified at such time in accordance with the requirements of this subsection, shall be entitled to continue to pay the amount of such tax or such lesser amount as may be levied in any year, as it becomes due each year following the death of such owner for as long as such surviving spouse or joint owner or joint tenant is qualified in accordance with the requirements in this subsection. After the first year a claim for such tax relief is filed and approved, application for such tax relief shall be filed biennially on a form prepared for such purpose by the town assessor. Any such owner or tenant who is qualified in accordance with this section and any such surviving spouse or joint owner or joint tenant surviving upon the death of such owner or tenant shall be entitled to pay such tax in the amount as provided in this section for so long as such owner or tenant or such surviving spouse or joint owner or joint tenant continues to be so qualified. To qualify for the tax relief provided in this section, a taxpayer shall meet all of the following requirements: 
a.  On December 31 of the calendar year preceding the year in which the claim is filed, be: 
1.  70 years of age or over; 
2.  The spouse of a person, 70 years of age or over, provided such spouse is domiciled with such person; or 
3.  62 years of age or over and the surviving spouse of a taxpayer who at the time of such taxpayer's death had qualified and was entitled to receive tax relief under this section, provided such surviving spouse was domiciled with such taxpayer at the time of the taxpayer's death; 
b.  Occupy such real property as his home; 
c.  Either spouse shall have resided within the state for at least one year before filing the claim under this section; 
d.  The taxable and nontaxable income of such taxpayer, the total of which shall hereinafter be called qualifying income, in the tax year of such homeowner ending immediately preceding the date of application for benefits under the program in this section, was not in excess of limits set forth in G.S. § 12-170aa, adjusted annually, evidence of which income shall be submitted to the town assessor in such form and manner as the assessor may prescribe. The amount of any Medicaid payments made on behalf of the homeowner or the spouse of such homeowner shall not constitute income. The income of the spouse of such homeowner shall not be included in the qualifying income of such homeowner for purposes of determining eligibility for tax relief under this section, if such spouse is a resident of a health care or nursing home facility in this state, and such facility receives payment related to such spouse under title XIX Medicaid program; 
e.  The assets of the taxpayer excluding the real property for which the taxpayer is seeking tax relief shall not exceed a value of $150,000.00. 
(2)  The tax on the real property for which the benefits of this section are claimed shall be the lower of: the tax due with respect to the homeowner's residence for the assessment year commencing October 1 of the year immediately preceding the year in which the initial claim for relief is made, or the tax due for any subsequent assessment year. If title to real property is recorded in the name of the person or the spouse making a claim and qualifying under this section and any other person, the claimant hereunder shall be entitled to pay the claimant's fractional share of the tax on such property calculated in accordance with the provisions of this section, and such other person shall pay the person's or persons' fractional share of the tax without regard for the provisions of this section. For the purposes of this section, the term "mobile manufactured home," as defined in G.S. § 12-63a shall be deemed to be real property. 
(3)  If any person with respect to whom a claim for tax relief in accordance with this section has been approved for any assessment year transfers, assigns, grants or otherwise conveys subsequent to October 1, but prior to August 1 in such assessment year, the interest in real property to which such claim for tax relief is related, regardless of whether such transfer, assignment, grant or conveyance is voluntary or involuntary, the amount of such tax relief benefit, determined as the amount by which the tax payable without benefit of this section exceeds the tax payable under the provisions of this section, shall be a pro rata portion of the amount otherwise applicable in such assessment year to be determined by a fraction of the numerator of which shall be the number of full months from October 1 in such assessment year to the date of such conveyance and the denominator of which shall be 12. If such conveyance occurs in the month of October, the grantor shall be disqualified for such tax relief in such assessment year. The grantee shall be required within a period not exceeding ten days immediately following the date of such conveyance to notify the assessor thereof, or in the absence of such notice, upon determination by the assessor that such transfer, assignment, grant or conveyance has occurred, the assessor shall determine the amount of tax relief benefit to which the grantor is entitled for such assessment year with respect to the interest in real property conveyed and notify the town collector of revenue of the reduced amount of such benefit. Upon receipt of such notice from the assessor, the collector of revenue shall, if such notice is received after the tax due date, no later than ten days thereafter mail or hand a bill to the grantee stating the additional amount of tax due as determined by the assessor. Such tax shall be due and payable and collectible as other property taxes and subject to the same liens and processes of collection, provided such tax shall be due and payable in an initial or single installment not sooner than 30 days after the date such bill is mailed or handed to the grantee and in equal amounts in any remaining, regular installments as the same are due and payable. 
(b)  Application; penalty. 
(1)  No claim shall be accepted under subsection (a) of this section unless the taxpayer or authorized agent of such taxpayer files an application with the assessor in which the property is located, in such form and manner as the assessor may prescribe, during the period from February 1 to and including May 15 of any year in which benefits are first claimed, including such information as is necessary to substantiate such a claim in accordance with the requirements in such application. A taxpayer may make application to the assessor prior to August 15 of the claim year for an extension of the application period. The assessor may grant such extension in the case of extenuating circumstances due to illness or incapacitation as evidenced by a physician's certificate to that extent, or if the assessor determines there is good cause for doing so. The taxpayer shall present to the assessor a copy of such taxpayer's federal income tax return and federal income tax return of such taxpayer's spouse, if filed separately, for such taxpayer's taxable year ending immediately prior to the submission of the taxpayer's application, or if not required to file a federal income tax return, such other evidence of qualifying income in respect to such taxable year as the assessor may require. Each such application, together with the federal income tax return and any other information submitted in relation thereto, shall be examined by the assessor and a determination shall be made as to whether the application is approved. Upon determination by the assessor that the applying homeowner is entitled to tax relief in accordance with the provisions of this section, the assessor shall notify the homeowner and the town collector of revenue of the approval of such application. The collector of revenue shall determine the maximum amount of tax due with respect to such homeowner's residence and thereafter the property tax with respect to such homeowner's residence shall not exceed such amount. After a taxpayer's claim for the first year has been filed and approved, such taxpayer shall file such an application biennially. In respect to such application required after the filing and approval for the first year the assessor shall notify each such taxpayer concerning application requirements by regular mail not later than February 1 of the assessment year in which such taxpayer is required to reapply, enclosing a copy of the required application form. Such taxpayer may submit such application to the assessor by mail provided it is received by the assessor not later than March 15 in the assessment year with respect to which such tax relief is claimed. Not later than April 1 of such year the assessor shall notify, by certified mail, any such taxpayer for whom such application was not received by said March 15 concerning application requirements and such taxpayer shall submit not later than May 15 such application personally, or, for reasonable cause, by a person acting on behalf of such taxpayer as approved by the assessor. 
(2)  Any person knowingly making a false application for the purpose of claiming property tax relief under this section shall be fined not more than $500.00. Any person who fails to disclose all matters relating thereto or with intent to defraud makes a false statement shall refund to the town all tax relief improperly taken. 
(3)  The town shall establish a lien on such property in the amount of the total tax relief granted, plus interest at a rate of three percent per year, applicable to the total unpaid taxes represented by such tax relief. Any such lien shall have a priority in the settlement of such person's estate. 
(4)  Upon approval of property tax relief granted to any such resident in accordance with the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the approved applicant shall cause the town to be named an additional insured on any homeowner's insurance policy insuring the subject property. 
(5)  Any such property tax relief granted to any such resident in accordance with the provisions of this section shall not disqualify such resident with respect to any benefits for which such resident shall be eligible under the provisions of G.S. §§ 12-129b through 12-129d, inclusive, and G.S. §§ 12-129n and 12-170aa and any such property tax relief provided under this section shall be in addition to any such benefits for which such resident shall be eligible under G.S. §§ 12-129b through 12-129d, inclusive, and G.S. §§ 12-129n and 12-170aa. 
(Ord. of 2-6-2008, §§ 1, 2) 
Chapter 19 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, ch. 17; vehicles used to transport solid waste, §§ 16-23-16-26. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate traffic generally, G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(B)(i); authority to regulate speed of vehicles, G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(B)(ii); authority restricted, G.S. § 14-162. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Speed limits. 
    The board of selectmen shall be authorized to fix the speed limit for all traffic on town highways, but in no case shall such speed limit be over 30 miles per hour. 
(Ord. of 11-19-1958) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate the speed of vehicles, G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(B)(ii). 
Sec. 19-2. - Street closure permit requirement for certain streets. 
(a)  No town street listed in subsection (c), or a lane or any portion of a lane of such street, shall be closed or work performed in any manner that would require any vehicles to have to stop, slow down, or deviate from the vehicle lane of such street in any manner without a street closure permit. Street closure permits shall not be required for work being conducted on private property. Applications for street closure permits shall be made on a form established by the first selectman and shall be submitted to the office of the first selectman. Street closure permit applications shall be reviewed by the first selectman working in concert with the highest ranking officer within the Portland Police Department. A street closure permit shall be issued provided the first selectman and said officer concur that the public health and safety can be protected thereby upon such terms and conditions as shall be set forth in the street closure permit. 
(b)  Whenever a private contractor or business needs to close any town street listed in subsection (c), or a lane or any portion of a lane of such street, or perform work in any manner that would require any vehicles to have to stop, slow down, or deviate from the vehicle lane of such street in any manner, the street closure permit may require that such contractor shall hire a police officer, if available, to direct traffic and ensure safety, unless deemed unnecessary by the first selectman (local traffic authority), and the highest ranking officer within the Portland Police Department or their designee. Town of Portland employees conducting official town work or Connecticut Department of Transportation employees conducting official state work on a state route or highway are exempt from the requirements of this section. Subcontractors of the town or state and/or private contractors hired by the town or state are not exempt from the requirements of this section. In the event that a contractor or business attempts to hire a police officer, and a private duty officer is unavailable, a supervisory officer shall conduct a job site assessment and will recommend to the construction foreman/employee proper traffic flow patterns and control around the construction site. 
(c)  The following town streets shall be covered under this section: Route 17 (Glastonbury Turnpike, Gospel Lane), Route 17A (Main Street), Route 66 (Arrigoni Bridge, Marlborough Street, Portland Cobalt Road), Ames Hollow Road, Bartlett Street, Fairview Street, Freestone Avenue, High Street, Isinglass Hill Road, Middle Haddam Road, Penfield Hill Road, Pepperidge Road, Spring Street, and William Street. 
(d)  A bond may be required in an amount as determined by the first selectman with the condition that the permit holder shall be liable to any person who shall receive injury as a result of the negligence of the permit holder and/or his/her officer, agents, servants and!or employees in doing said acts or failing to do said acts. The street closure permit shall also have the condition that the permit holder shall hold harmless and indemnify the Town of Portland, its officers, agents, servants and employees against loss or penalty arising from injuries (including death) and/or damages resulting from the action or inaction of the permit holder, his/her officers, agents, servants and employees. 
(e)  No street closure permit shall be issued until the applicant provides the office of the first selectman with a certificate of insurance evidencing comprehensive broad form general liability insurance, including but not limited to contractual, premises and operations, products/completed operations, independent contractors, broad form property damage and bodily injury liability insurance in the minimum amount of $1,000,000.00 combined single limits, special risk insurance covering underground explosion and collapse hazard in the minimum amount of $1,000,000.00, automobile liability insurance in the minimum amount of $1,000,000.00 combined single limit, workers' compensation insurance to meet the minimum statutory requirements and employer's liability insurance in the minimum amounts of $100,000.00 each accident, $100,000.00 disease - each employee, and $500,000.00 disease - policy limit. With the exception of workers' compensation and employer's liability insurance, said certificate of insurance shall name the Town of Portland, its officers, agents, servants and employees as additional insureds. 
(f)  A violation of any provision of this section shall be an infraction subject to a fine of $90.00. 
(Ord. of 5-4-2011) 
Secs. 19-3-19-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Parking authorities, G.S. § 7-202 et seq. 

Sec. 19-21. - Fire zones, no parking. 
(a)  The fire marshal for the town, or his designate, is hereby directed and authorized pursuant to G.S. § 29-293 to establish fire lanes within or near public or private street, highway or passway, for the safety of the general public. Such areas shall be restricted no parking. 
(b)  Wherever the fire marshal establishes a fire lane, he shall file a copy of his orders with the town clerk's office. Such restricted areas shall be clearly marked, at owner's expense, "No parking-Fire lane." 
(c)  The enforcement of this section shall be the responsibility of the chief of police and whomsoever he may delegate. 
(d)  Violators of this section shall be fined up to $100.00 payable to the centralized infractions bureau (P.O. Box 5044, Hartford, CT 06102-5044) within 21 days. Towing and storage costs shall conform to rates as established by state regulations and shall be paid by the owner of the towed vehicle. 
(Ord. of 5-25-1988(2); Ord. of 9-2-2009, § 19-21(a), (b)) 
Sec. 19-22. - Snow and ice removal. 
(a)  Plowing, throwing into street. No person shall plow, throw, put or cause to be thrown or put any snow or ice from any private property or from any area of such private property or in the area between a private dwelling house or structure and the legally laid-out sidewalk, into any public highway in the town. 
(b)  Parking bans. The first selectman, upon the advice of the director of public works, shall have the authority to invoke an emergency parking ban throughout the town. Violators of this parking ban shall not be fined more than $99.00 plus the expenses of towing if same becomes necessary. 
(c)  Rules and regulations. When a parking ban has been invoked by the first selectman pursuant to subsection (b) of this section, the director of public works shall have the authority to make rules and regulations in regard to the orderly clearing, plowing and removal of snow in the town. 
(d)  Payment of violations. Any person receiving a parking infraction for a violation of a parking ban invoked under subsection (b) above shall follow the instructions as provided on the back of the infractions/complaint form for the state. 
(Ord. of 10-14-1987(4)) 
Cross reference- Snow and ice on sidewalks, § 17-96 et seq. 
Sec. 19-23. - Parking violations in specific locations-$5.00 penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park more than 12 inches from the curb; or within ten feet of a hydrant; or in a loading and unloading zone; or in obstruction of a driveway; or on the sidewalk; or on the wrong side of the street; or within 25 feet of a corner; or within 25 feet of a stop sign. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park in a no parking area; or in an area marked as a bus stop; or in an intersection; or to double-park. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park in any area that is a temporary no parking area for the removal of snow or ice. 
(d)  The penalty for violating any of the provisions of this section shall be $5.00. 
(Ord. of 10-30-1980(1), § 1) 
Sec. 19-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Feb. 22, 1995, repealed former § 19-24, relative to a $10.00 penalty for parking violations, which derived from § 2 of an ordinance adopted Oct. 30, 1980. 
Sec. 19-25. - Parking violations in specific locations-Payment of penalties. 
    Each owner or operator of a vehicle parked in violation of section 19-23 or 19-24 may, within five days of the time when notice of such violation was attached to his vehicle, pay to the office of the first selectman or duly designated representative, the penalty for and in full satisfaction of a parking violation. The failure of such owner or operator to make such payment within such time limit shall render such owner or operator subject to double the penalty provided for such violation. 
(Ord. of 10-30-1980(1), § 3) 
Secs. 19-26-19-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ABANDONED AND INOPERABLE VEHICLES 

Sec. 19-40. - Generally. 
(a)  This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Ordinance Governing the Parking of Motor Vehicles." 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to adopt provisions concerning the parking of motor vehicles on private and public property in order to protect the general welfare of the people of the town. 
(Ord. of 6-27-2007(1), § 19-40) 
Sec. 19-41. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Abandoned, inoperative or discarded motor vehicle means a motor vehicle which is in a state of disuse, neglect, or abandonment, a motor vehicle without a license plate, a motor vehicle with a license plate that is not registered to that motor vehicle, a motor vehicle that does not have a registration sticker, or a motor vehicle that has a registration sticker which has been expired for a period of at least 90 days. Evidence of disuse, neglect or abandonment may include, but is not limited to factors such as: vehicle being wrecked and inoperative; inoperative as evidenced by vegetation underneath as high as the vehicle body or frame; refuse or debris collected underneath or the vehicle being used solely for storage purposes; if it is partially dismantled, having no engine, transmission, or other major and visible parts; having major and visible parts which are dismantled; incapable of functioning as a motor vehicle in its present state; has only nominal salvage value; or being in any physical state rendering it inoperative. The enforcement officer shall use his training and experience to determine whether, under the totality of the circumstances, the vehicle is in a state of evident disuse, neglect or abandonment. A vehicle will be considered abandoned or derelict if it is in an evident state of extended disuse or neglect. 
    Carport means an open-sided structure which is used solely for the parking of motor vehicles which belong to the occupants of the principal building. 
    Dismantled motor vehicle means a motor vehicle which has been completely separated into pieces or components for a period of at least seven days. 
    Enforcement officer means the zoning enforcement officer, police officers, or any other person designated by the first selectperson. 
    Garage means a walled accessory building or walled portion of the principal building, excluding a carport, which is used for the parking of motor vehicles which belong to the occupants of the principal building. 
    Inoperative motor vehicle: See abandoned, inoperative or discarded motor vehicle. 
    Motor vehicle has the same meaning as set forth in G.S. § 14-1 and includes boats of any type. The term "motor vehicle" includes, but is not limited to, automobiles, busses, motorbikes, motorcycles, motorscooters, trucks, tractors, recreational vehicles, campers, snowmobiles, and trailers, including utility trailers, except any vehicle that is operated principally on a farm, grove, or orchard in an agricultural zoned area in connection with a bona fide agricultural, horticultural, or livestock pursuit. 
    Nominal salvage value means a salvage value of not more than $300.00, as appraised under standard practices by a motor vehicle salvage dealer. 
    Parked means the standing of a motor vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or embarking or disembarking passengers. 
    Partly dismantled motor vehicle means a motor vehicle which has been partially separated into pieces or components for a period of at least seven days. 
    Severely rusted motor vehicle means a motor vehicle which, excluding its windows, windshield, and underside, is rusted on at least 50 percent of its body exterior. 
    Standard cover means a nontransparent cover which is designed, manufactured and intended to be used exclusively for the purpose of fitting over the type of motor vehicle in question. 
    Wrecked motor vehicle means a motor vehicle which is in a state of ruin or dilapidation or in a condition of broken, disrupted, and disordered parts. 
(b)  No person shall oppose, obstruct or resist any enforcement officer or any person authorized by the enforcement officer in the discharge of his duties, as provided in this article. 
(Ord. of 6-27-2007(1), § 19-41) 
Sec. 19-42. - Findings of fact. 
(a)  Aesthetic views on private and public property, including streets and rights-of-way relate to the general welfare of the people of the town through the tendency of the former to preserve or enhance the value of property. 
(b)  The visual presence on private and public property, including streets and rights-of-way in such zoned areas, of wrecked, discarded, dismantled, partly dismantled, inoperative, abandoned, or severely rusted motor vehicles, and/or motor vehicles which, if covered, are covered with something other than a standard cover, is an unpleasant sight to the eyes of the reasonable person of average sensibilities. 
(c)  The visual presence on public or private property, including streets and rights-of-way in such zoned areas, of wrecked, discarded, dismantled, partly dismantled, inoperative, abandoned, or severely rusted motor vehicles, and/or motor vehicles which, if covered, are covered with something other than a standard cover, is a visual nuisance in that it tends to depreciate the value of neighboring public or private property, thereby injuring the general welfare of the people of the town. 
(Ord. of 6-27-2007(1), § 19-42) 
Sec. 19-43. - Visual nuisance declared; abatement required; citation. 
(a)  Any motor vehicle which is parked on public or private property, including streets or rights-of-way, in violation of this article is declared to be a visual nuisance which is detrimental to the general welfare of the people of the town. 
(b)  If a motor vehicle is parked in violation of this article, the visual nuisance may be abated as provided by this article. A violation of this article shall be a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. of 6-27-2007(1), § 19-43) 
Sec. 19-44. - Motor vehicles required to be parked in garage. 
    Any vehicle covered by this article may not be parked on public or private property, including streets and rights-of-way, unless it is either parked inside a completely enclosed garage or parked completely within a carport and covered with a standard cover, or in the rear of the property, or least visible location from the street, provided that it is not stored on the waterfront side of any property located adjacent to a pond, river or lake. In any event, where the vehicle is stored on the side or rear of the property, the offending property owner shall erect a fence or maintain a hedge of sufficient height to block the view of the vehicle by the adjacent property owner. 
(Ord. of 6-27-2007(1), § 19-44) 
Sec. 19-45. - Motor vehicles are required to be covered with standard cover unless parked in garage. 
    Any motor vehicle which is parked on public or private property, including streets and right-of-ways, that is covered shall be covered with nothing other than a standard cover, unless it is parked inside a completely enclosed garage. 
(Ord. of 6-27-2007(1), § 19-45) 
Sec. 19-46. - Responsibility. 
    The owner, renter, or agent of the public or private property upon which a violation of this article occurs, and the owner of the motor vehicle which is parked in violation of this article shall be jointly and individually responsible for not complying with this article. 
(Ord. of 6-27-2007(1), § 19-46) 
Sec. 19-47. - Notice, penalty for violation. 
(a)  The enforcement officer may issue a notice: 
(1)  To the owner of the property where a violation exists under the provisions of this article; and 
(2)  To the owner of the relevant motor vehicle or parts, if known. 
(b)  The notice shall request that such vehicles or parts be removed from the property or that the owner comply with the provisions of this article within 30 days after such notice. Such notice shall be sent both by regular mail and by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(c)  No later than seven days after such notice is mailed, the enforcement officer shall cause a copy of such notice to be published in a newspaper having a general circulation within the town. 
(d)  If the motor vehicles or the parts referred to in the notice are not removed or if the owner does not comply with the provisions of this article within 30 days after the publication of the notice, the town may take one or both of the following actions: 
(1)  The enforcement agent may issue an infraction ticket to the owner of the vehicle or parts, if known. The amount of the ticket shall be $90.00 for each vehicle that is in violation of this article, and $90.00, collectively, for any motor vehicle parts that are in violation of this article.
